To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.Dame Judi Dench and Joanna Lumley are among the stars who have today urged Londoners to bid on sections of Sir Peter Blake’s pop artwork Our Fans to raise money for Help the Hungry.Last Friday, The Independent announced that the giant mural — draped over the London Mandarin Oriental hotel in Knightsbridge during its 2017 renovation — would be cut into 100 sections and auctioned off.The work, which echoes Sir Peter’s famous 1967 artwork for The Beatles’ Sgt Pepper album, is his largest piece, the size of 38 London buses. Each section features a famous face, including Morgan Freeman, Whoopi Goldberg and Sir Paul McCartney, and is signed by Sir Peter, 87.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesProceeds will go to two beneficiaries, including The Independent's Help The Hungry Now appeal partner The Felix Project.Today, Ms Lumley said it was an “honour” to be part of the fundraising effort. She said: “Double honour — to be a face in Peter Blake’s awesome collage for the Mandarin and to be a tiny part of helping Help the Hungry. It is a fabulous way of making life worth living.”Help the Hungry: Our readers help us reach £6.5mDame Judi said: “How wonderful that Peter Blake’s amazing artwork will have a new lease of life for such good causes. I’m very glad that maybe my left eyebrow has gone to good use.”Italian actress Caterina Murino, who also stars in the work, said: “The world is upside down. We fight for our life, we fight for the life of our brothers, and this is the feeling I have when I contemplate Sir Peter Blake’s masterpiece! A hundred stars that reflect the ersity of our world fighting to help Help the Hungry. I can’t be more honoured.”The piece was originally commissioned by London Advertising, whose founder Michael Moszynski said: “We’re looking forward to seeing the final figures raised.Help the hungry&nbsp|&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: help the hungry school children meals felix project ocado
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'These generous new donations take us 70 per cent of the way towards our goal to secure £10m to combat food poverty in London over the next three years,' says The Independent's Evgeny LebedevThe Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.Our Help The Hungry appeal today passed the £7m mark, enabling our appeal partner, The Felix Project, to deliver the equivalent of 4.3 million meals to hungry schoolchildren and vulnerable Londoners in the 12 weeks since lockdown began.The milestone was reached thanks to more significant corporate donations, including an additional £100,000 from online grocer Ocado, taking its total donation to £390,000, and a further £90,000 from banking group Citi boosting their aggregate give to £250,000.It comes as the charity Feeding Britain warns that 3 million children face the prospect of hunger during the upcoming school holidays. Of these, it cautions, only 1 million are eligible for the government’s free school meal summer holiday voucher of £15 a week, with the remaining 2 million living with parents who narrowly do not qualify but cannot always afford food.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHelen Barnard, of the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, confirmed that the summer voucher scheme – agreed by the prime minister after being forced into a U-turn by footballer Marcus Rashford – only covers a minority of children in poverty. She said: “Soaring numbers of families are being pulled under and having to rely on food banks to get through the current crisis, even with the voucher scheme in place.”The harsh reality is that an astounding 66 per cent of food-insecure families – amounting to almost 200,000 children in London – cannot access government help and are forced to rely on food parcels from charities such as The Felix Project.Food and 10,000 face coverings donated to charities and vulnerableWhich star will you bid for in Peter Blake’s big hotel cover auction?Help the Hungry: Our readers help us reach £6.5mHow Help The Hungry is helping refugees forced to live on £5 a day At the start of lockdown, The Felix Project faced an existential crisis with a total collapse of its fundraising. Thanks to The Independent’s campaign, it has not only been able to survive but has operated at twice its normal capacity, delivering up to 40 tons of nutritious produce a day and supplying 86 schools and 400 charities and community hubs across the capital over the course of a week.The Independent shareholder Evgeny Lebedev said: “These generous new donations take us 70 per cent of the way towards our goal to secure £10m to combat food poverty in London over the next three years. Our pledge is given added urgency by the release of worrying economic data, including that the number of people out of work and claiming benefits jumped 23 per cent to 2.8 million last month.”Jo West, of Ocado Retail, said most of its donation had been raised from Ocado and their customers via their “you give, we give” scheme. She added: “We’re extremely grateful to our customers for their generosity which enables groups like The Felix Project to bring food to people in desperate need.” James Murray, chair of the Bridgepoint Charitable Trust, which donated £50,000, said: “We are delighted to contribute to the work of The Felix Project in feeding vulnerable communities.”Help the hungry&nbsp|&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: public transport boost england july bus tube
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Bus and train timetables to return to 85 per cent of pre-coronavirus levelsThe Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.The Department of Transport has announced that public transport services will be increased in England from early July, though they will not rise as high as pre-pandemic levels. Bus timetables will reach 85 per cent of their former levels from 4 July, while train schedules will follow suit two days later. However, the government still recommends that people avoid public transport where possible. Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesGrant Shapps, the transport secretary, said: As more businesses across the country prepare to reopen, we are increasing rail and bus services to boost capacity and meet additional demand for travel, helping people to travel safely.Our guidance remains that people should avoid public transport if possible and to walk or cycle instead.Transport secretary offers no promises to ease travel quarantineDo I need to wear a face covering on public transport?End of lockdown ‘could result in worst congestion ever’Google Maps adds coronavirus warnings to directionsFace coverings made compulsory on public transport from 15 JuneIn a message posted on Twitter on Thursday, Mr Shapps also reminded passengers that they need to wear face coverings on public transport in England and Scotland. The announcement about a boost in public transport came just days after the prime minister introduced that new coronavirus guidelines would come into force early next month.Boris Johnson said earlier this week that indoor gatherings of people from two households will be allowed from 4 July, while the two-metre social distancing will be relaxed to a one metre plus policy. The new rules, which mark the most significant easing of restrictions since lockdown was introduced on 23 March, also allow pubs, restaurants, cinemas and hotels to reopen from 4 July.The hospitality sector has been particularly hard-hit by lockdown, with thousands of businesses shutting for more than three months. As a result, Robert Lingard, the founder of National Hospitality Week, has called on the government to create a universal travel voucher to promote internal tourism and help save thousands of businesses and hospitality jobs. title: brexit no deal proposal eu uk chief negotiator
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.David Frost stamps on idea that&nbspUK could have ability to break free from EU rules – in return for tariff punishment if it takes that pathA proposal seen as the best chance of avoiding a disastrous no-deal Brexit at the end of the year has been rejected by the UK’s chief negotiator.With the talks deadlocked, it was thought the EU could agree to give the UK the ability to break free from its rules – in return for the right to impose tariffs if it chose to do so.The arrangement would have avoided the feared cliff-edge on 31 December, when the UK will crash out of the single market and customs union unless an agreement is struck.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesBut, in a series of tweets, David Frost, Boris Johnson’s negotiator, announced: “I want to be clear that the government will not agree to ideas like the one currently circulating giving the EU a new right to retaliate with tariffs if we chose to make laws suiting our interests.“We could not leave ourselves open to such unforeseeable economic risk.”Minister won’t comment on chlorinated chicken, claiming US listeningBritish officials had suggested Boris Johnson would consider the compromise, under which the UK would secure the right to deviate from Brussels’ standards in areas such as state aid.The EU was thought to be sceptical – preferring to strike a firm deal, rather than set a path for future conflict in the relationship – but had welcomed what it viewed as new-found flexibility in London.After clashes following recent remote negotiations, optimism had crept up that an agreement could be reached when face-to-face talks resume next week.But, without the proposed fudge – kicking key decisions into the future – the two sides remain at odds over access to UK fishing waters and title: chlorinated chicken brexit us trade deal hormone beef
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'Dual tariff' plan raised in&nbspWashington allowing US food producers to sell products that does not comply with British standards if they pay higher leviesThe environment secretary has said laws barring chlorinated chicken and hormone-fed beef won't change to secure a trade deal with the US - despite a previous pledge to maintain the ban being dropped by No 10.George Eustice said the UK was not under any obligation to change its approach amid concerns from farmers and campaigners that the government could lower standards on imported produce as part of trade with the US.Donald Trump's administration has made it clear that it will not allow American farmers to be disadvantaged in a US-UK trade deal, with US trade representative Robert Lighthizer describing concerns about farming practices as thinly veiled protectionism.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMinisters are said to have put forward a dual tariff plan to Washington, that would allow US food producers to sell products that does not comply with British standards if they paid higher levies.The move would mark a significant loosening of the current rules, where the UK complies with strict European welfare and sanitary standards.Minister won’t comment on chlorinated chicken, claiming US listeningAsked to guarantee that UK law would not change, Mr Eustice told the Today programme: I can't bind the hands of any future government, as you will know.This government is clear, we were the ones that brought across the prohibition on the use of washes such as chlorine and hormones in beef and we won't change that.Mr Eustice said the UK had to be open to considering approaches that other countries might bring to us under trading rules but we're not under any obligation to change it.He said the Conservatives had made a manifesto commit to protect food standards and animal welfare, which would be central to the ongoing trade talks.However his comments come after Liz Truss, the international trade secretary, refused to tell MPs about the proposed deal in case the US trade negotiators were listening.“I’m not going to go into detail in this committee on our negotiating strategy, because I suspect our counterparties from across the Atlantic might be taking account of my comments,” she said.Earlier this month, Downing Street dropped a pledge to maintain bans on chlorinated chicken and hormone-fed beef, as post-Brexit trade talks ramp up with Washington.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: schools england return coronavirus classrooms rules guidelines summer
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Secondary and primary school children&nbspare emerging from lockdown and back into classrooms. Here are some of the measures that schools are implementing to make the transition easier for pupils, staff and parentsIn association with the UK GovernmentHinchingbrooke School is an academy school in Huntingdon, Cambridgeshire, with more than 1,900 pupils and 200 staff. Teachers started welcoming back A-level students last week.“We’ve only had the Year 12s in so far, but for them it was really clear they were delighted to be back,” says Mark Patterson, school principal, pictured above. “You could see it on their faces. It’s getting back to some sense of routine, structure and normality.He continues: “I think a lot of them have been surprised by how much they’ve missed school. I think if you’d asked them before lockdown ‘Would you like a week off?’, they’d have said ‘Please!’. I bet if you asked them now, they’d say ‘Can I come back?’. I think the parents and students now realise how important school is.”Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesPrior to the return, teachers organised a virtual assembly for Year 10 and 12 pupils, and sent a booklet home detailing the new guidelines which would be in place.5 back-to-school tips for parents&nbsp“Don't give them a lot of small instructions – recognise your child would have had an enormous amount of&nbspinstructions during the course of the day.”“If you are rewarding your child's behaviour, it's very important to do it every time.”“For a child who's been finding it tough,&nbsptalking to another child who's been in the same situation is by far the best way of letting it out.”“It's important to encourage a child to work for themselves and get on with their own inner task.”New measures include red circles marked on the ground that are two metres apart and one-way systems throughout the school.“We’ve reorganised all the classrooms that we’re using so the desks and chairs are two metres apart,” Patterson explains. “We’ve got designated areas set aside at break and lunchtime for each group to go to, and we’ve got signage around the school reminding everybody of the importance of hygiene, frequent hand washing and keeping their distance.”Implementing new measuresRheeya Makwana is one of the Year 12 students who has returned to Hinchingbrooke. “We’ve been having online lessons and voiceover PowerPoints, but it’s not really the same as being in a classroom,” she says. “The structure was really good and I felt like I learned a lot more being back at school. I came home in such a good mood.”Rheeya’s father Yogesh Makwana did have some initial worries about his daughter returning to school: “There’s always some concern, but all the communication from school has been excellent in the build up to it and all the measures that have been put in place have reassured us. If you offered our 13-year-old the chance to go back to school tomorrow, he’d do it in a heartbeat. He misses his classes the social interaction. He loves PE and he does so much at school that he misses.Year 10 pupils Vahine and Lucia will also be returning to the school this week. “The twins are really looking forward to it,” says their mother, Alesia Dickinson. “They’ve been messaging all their friends to find out what group they’re in. Less than a week after we said yes to going back we found out what bubbles they were in and we had clear guidelines about times, rooms and what they can expect when they go back to school. They’re raring to go.”Both Makwana and Dickinson agree that their children have missed the structure of school lessons and that the transition back to the classroom has been easier than expected. “I think it’s a positive thing,” says Dickinson. “I think it’s a step in the right direction. We need to let the children start that process.”Going back to Embark schoolsTrust leader at Embark Matthew Crawford, pictured below, has been welcoming back primary pupils to the Federation’s schools across Derbyshire.“The feedback we have had so far from all the schools across the Trust is that it’s going really well in terms of welcoming the children back,” he says. “It’s not a one-size-fits-all. Each school has done a risk assessment based on what they can do.”Most Embark schools are now back at around 25-30 per cent capacity, Crawford says. It's up from around two per cent when lockdown began, when it was just key workers’ children and more vulnerable pupils in the classroom.“It’s lovely to hear the children playing and see schools becoming vibrant again,” he adds. “As soon as lockdown began, we started work on our Reconnection to Recovery and Resilience programme, a nine-stage support package to welcome children back safely.”Keyworker Vicki Ellis has two children who have returned to one of Embark's schools Richardson Endowed Primary - Amelia in Year 3 and Darcey in Year 1, pictured below.The first day the girls were back I was wondering how they were all day. I knew the school had done everything possible to welcome the children back in a happy, positive way but I worried whether Amelia and Darcey were enjoying themselves. But when they came home they were so happy to have had that day at school – and eager to go back next day. Crawford explains that the school has tried to make the transition back to the classroom as fun as possible for the children: “We’re following the guidelines but in a way that’s fun for the children. We aren’t marking big Xs on the floor. Some of our schools, for example, are painting snakes in bright colours to show the way.”Embark has also shared its programme with schools as far as Devon, Durham, South Gloucestershire and Wales.“It’s a suite of resources and activities that schools can adapt to their own settings, taking the bits that work for them,” explains Crawford. “It’s lovely that the brilliant work of our staff is making a difference and impacting the lives of millions of children across the country, not just the 3,000 within our Trust.”Information in this article applies to schools in England only. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Japan will discuss ways to protect country and people from north’s missiles and other threats, says defence ministerThe Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.Japan’s National Security Council has endorsed plans to cancel the deployment of two costly land-based US missile defence systems aimed at bolstering the country’s capability against threats from North Korea, the country’s defence minister said on Thursday.Defence minister Taro Kono said the country will now revise its missile defence programme and scale up its entire defence posture.The council made its decision on Wednesday, and now the government will need to enter negotiations with the US about what to do with payments and the purchase contract already made for the Aegis Ashore systems.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMr Kono announced the plan to scrap the systems earlier this month after it was found that the safety of one of the two planned host communities could not be ensured without a hardware redesign that would be too time-consuming and costly.“We couldn’t move forward with this project, but still there are threats from North Korea,” Mr Kono said at a news conference on Thursday.Japan tells UK to agree to trade terms in six weeks or face disruptionJapan won’t pay half of foreign tourists’ costsJapan ends nationwide state of emergencyCinemas start to reopen in Japan, showing old Hollywood classicsJapan’s reliance on fax machines lambasted by coronavirus doctorJapan will discuss ways to better protect the country and the people from the north’s missiles and other threats, he said.The Japanese government in 2017 approved adding the two Aegis Ashore systems to enhance the country’s current defences consisting of Aegis-equipped destroyers at sea and Patriot missiles on land.Defence officials have said the two Aegis Ashore units could cover Japan entirely from one station at Yamaguchi in the south and another at Akita in the north.The plan to deploy the two systems already had faced a series of setbacks, including questions about the selection of one of the sites, repeated cost estimate hikes that climbed to 450bn yen (£3.3bn) for their 30-year operation and maintenance, and safety concerns that led to local opposition.Mr Kono said Japan has signed a contract worth nearly half the total cost and paid part of it to the US. He said Japan is trying to get the most out of what it has already paid, though he did not elaborate.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailPrime minister Shinzo Abe, who has steadily pushed to step up Japan’s defence capability, said last week that in light of the scrapping the government would need to reconsider Japan’s missile defence programme and do more under the country’s security alliance with the US.Mr Abe said the government would consider the possibility of acquiring preemptive strike capability, a controversial plan that critics say would violate Japan’s war-renouncing constitution.Mr Kono on Thursday also raised concern about China’s increasingly assertive activity in regional seas and skies. He said Chinese coast guard vessels are repeatedly in and out of Japanese waters around disputed East China Sea islands, and a Chinese submarine recently passed just off Japan’s southern coast.“China is trying to change the status quo unilaterally in East China Sea, South China Sea and with Indian border and Hong Kong as well,” Mr Kono said. “It is easy to make connections about those issues.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.And which countries are yet to even reach the peak?The Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.Coronavirus lockdowns are lifting around the world, raising concerns that it could trigger a new wave of infections.Some countries that experienced a significant drop in new Covid-19 cases in April and May are now beginning to experience an uptick in confirmed daily cases.The concerning trend can be seen in several countries throughout the Middle East, most notably in Iran where new cases briefly dropped below 1,000 in early May but have now more than doubled.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIran was one of the first countries to experience a significant outbreak of the deadly virus, with close to 200,000 total cases recorded.Looking at a smoothed seven-day rolling average for new daily cases, Iran's second wave came almost exactly one month after the first wave.The data suggests that Iran may have already reached the peak of its second wave and is now on the decline.Other countries in the region appear to be experiencing a more gradual second wave, with official figures from Israel revealing that new coronavirus cases have been rising consistently for the past three weeks.Israel's second wave remains a long way off the peak of the first wave, and the country remains one of the least affected in the Middle East.In Saudi Arabia, new cases are rising at record rates despite briefly appearing to peak in late May.The false peak means the latest surge of new cases could be counted as a continuation of the first wave, rather than a new second wave.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailTurkey is second only to Iran in terms of total coronavirus cases in the Middle East, and is also beginning to show early signs of a second wave of infections.Recent online search trends in the United States have hinted that a second wave may be on its way, however there is yet to be a sustained drop in new cases since a massive increase in March and April.With more than 2.1 million confirmed cases, the US is by far the worst affected country in the world and has not dropped below 20,000 new daily cases since 1 April.The United Kingdom was briefly the second worst hit country globally but has seen a consistent fall in new cases throughout May and June.With more than 1,000 new confirmed cases each day it continues to be the worst affected country in Europe.Most worryingly of all are the countries that continue to see the number of new cases climb each day.India has seen the number of new cases of Covid-19 rise nearly every day since the virus first came to the country in March, with more than 10,000 cases now recorded each day.A similar situation can be seen in Mexico, where the peak of the first wave appears to not yet have been reached.A new outbreak also appears to be taking hold in Beijing, though official figures from the Chinese capital suggest that it is still relatively small. title: coronavirus yemen children starvation unief report
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Situation&nbspis only expected to get worse as donor countries recently cut back on aidThe Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.Unicef has warned that millions of children could be pushed to the brink of starvation as the coronavirus pandemic sweeps across war-torn Yemen amid a “huge” drop in humanitarian aid funding.It said the number of malnourished Yemeni children could reach 2.4 million by the end of the year, a 20 per cent increase on the current figure.The stark prediction comes in a new report by the UN’s children’s agency, entitled “Yemen five years on: children, conflict and Covid-19”.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe agency warned: “As Yemen’s devastated health system and infrastructure struggle to cope with coronavirus, the already dire situation for children is likely to deteriorate considerably.”Yemen’s poor health care infrastructure is unprepared to battle the coronavirus pandemic after five years of war between a Saudi-led military coalition and the Iranian-backed Houthi rebels.Houthi rebels fire missiles at Riyadh amid surge of violence in YemenSaudi Arabia co-hosts UN funding summit for war-torn Yemen Coronavirus fears compound dire situation for pregnant women in YemenThe Saudi and UAE cold war in Yemen will only intensifyYemen separatists declare self-rule in the south after seizing AdenThe war has also triggered the world’s worst humanitarian crisis.The conflict erupted in 2015 when the Saudi-led coalition stepped in on behalf of the internationally recognised government, which the Houthis had forced into exile when they overran the capital, Sanaa, and much of the north the previous year.The situation in Yemen is only expected to get worse as donor countries recently cut back on aid.Yemen has officially recorded more than 1,000 cases of Covid-19, the illness caused by the coronavirus, including 275 deaths.However, the actual tally is believed to be much higher as testing capabilities are severely limited.Sara Beysolow Nyanti, Unicef’s representative to Yemen, said: “If we do not receive urgent funding, children will be pushed to the brink of starvation and many will die.“The international community will be sending a message that the lives of children ... simply do not matter.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailUnicef also warned that unless $54.5m (£43.8m) is disbursed for health and nutrition aid by the end of August, more than 23,000 children will be at increased risk of dying because of acute malnutrition. It also said that five million others under the age of five will not have access to vaccines against deadly diseases.International relief agencies are alarmed by the significant decline in humanitarian funding promised earlier by donor countries.A virtual pledging conference for Yemen hosted by the UN and Saudi Arabia on 2 June saw 31 donors pledge $1.35bn (£1.08bn) for humanitarian aid – $1bn (£805m) short of what aid agencies needed, and half of what countries had pledged in 2019.Unicef could only secure 10 per cent of the $461m (£371m) it appealed for to cover its humanitarian response to the crisis in Yemen, and less than 40 per cent of the $53m (£42m) it needs to handle the impact of Covid-19 on children, said the report.Houthi rebels fire missile at Riyadh amid surge of violence in YemenMs Nyanti said: “Unicef is working around the clock in incredibly difficult situations to get aid to children in desperate need, but we only have a fraction of the funding required to do this.”The report follows a warning by UN humanitarian chief Mark Lowcock, who told a closed UN Security Council meeting that Yemen could “fall off the cliff” without massive financial support.Mr Lowcock added that Covid-19 is spreading rapidly across the Arab world’s poorest country, killing about 25 per cent of confirmed cases – five times the global average.Half of Yemen’s health facilities are dysfunctional and 18 per cent of the country’s 333 districts have no doctors.Water and sanitation systems have collapsed, resulting in recurrent cholera outbreaks.Around 9.6 million children do not have sufficient access to safe water, sanitation, or hygiene, and two-thirds of the country’s roughly 30 million people rely on food assistance.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin title: who are jonty braverys parents
story: While being cared for in the community, he had chucked stuff out of the window, including rubbish and poo, according to a neighbour.Jonty Bravery has admitted throwing a French boy, six, ft from the tourist attractions viewing  on August , .He had reportedly told carers he wanted to throw someone off a high building a year earlier.A court heard in December that the teen suffered from autistic spectrum disorder, obsessive compulsive disorder and a probable personality disorder.Jontys dad is Piers Bravery, , the company director of a printing firm, according to Companies House records.His mum is a former air hostess, reports the Daily Mail.It adds that when Jonty - born in West London - was three, his parents parted and have new families.As a youngster, he was taught at several special needs schools, but envied the more normal lives of his relatives.The Mail says that his father raised funds for a special needs centre, which he described as incredibly caring and understanding to my son Jonty.The Press Association reports that, in a series of social media posts - since deleted - Piers tried to raise awareness of autism and its treatment.In one tweet to Health Secretary Matt Hancock, posted less than three months before the incident, he said: “Yes, @MattHancock, you do have a duty.You are a public servant so do your job and stop more children dying and being abused in these repugnant institutions.”His son was sectioned in , under the Mental Health Act, and removed from his home.Some time later, he was living in a residential flat in Northolt, London.West London NHS Trust told The Times that Jonty had been placed under the responsibility of Hammersmith and Fulham council.However, a council spokeswoman said the authority had only contributed to his care package and the trust made the decision he should be cared for in the community.A neighbour, who asked not to be named, told The Times that Jonty was living with two carers. They come in shts. He has to go with somebody when he goes out,Another neighbour added that Jonty had been seen chucking stuff out of the window on to the grass [including] rubbish [and] faeces.Defence counsel Philippa McAtasney told the Old Bailey that Braverys parents abhor what he did at the Tate Modern, and cannot forgive him, but feel let down by the system.A Hammersmith  Fulham Council spokesman said a serious case review was under way, and the authority was co-operating fully and would learn from its findings.The mentally ill and violent Bravery has been told he may never be released from prison.He was jailed for  years at the Old Bailey on June , after admitting attempted murder.Judge Mrs Justice McGowan said: The fear hemust have experienced and the horror his parents felt are beyond imagination.He has been in custody at Broadmoor Hospital, a high-security psychiatric hospital at Crowthorne, Berkshire, since mid-October .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: opening pubs but not schools doesnt add up
story: PRAISE the Lord – the decision is made. You can now at last be within ft in of someone outside your immediate household! What’s more, from July , you will be able to eat in restaurants, have a drink and, of course, continue shopping.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesWhat you won’t be able to do, unless you are very fortunate, is to get your children into school, which says something about our national priorities. Make no mistake about it, this is a “national emergency”. Education should have the upfront priority that we rightly give the NHS and saving our economy. The failure since the beginning of March to plan ahead for getting all schools and all youngsters back into the classroom has been reprehensible.I say all schools because the majority have been open for the children of key workers and for children designated as vulnerable.Many teachers have been doing a first-class job trying to keep in touch with children at home, providing them with online tuition, homework and marking. But there is still time to mobilise all the necessary resources to make it possible to get children back to school for at least a couple of weeks before the end of this term.Yes, it would involve finding extra premises for schools with inadequate space. Yes, we would have to appeal to teachers who have recently retired to come back for perhaps a few hours a week. Yes, we would need to employ supply teachers.In addition we could use university students, who won’t be finding summer jobs any time soon, to assist.Of course, we don’t have that reliable summer weather that will allow teaching outside on a regular basis, butDenmark can place many lessons in an outside setting, we can.If the French, Lord help us, can get their schools mobilised and back to full operation, we can. Their trade unions are far more bolshy than ours, and teachers regrettably much less well paid.So we need a combination of creativity, imagination and drive to get pupils back. We need to rebuild the confidence of parents and staff that they are highly unlikely to contract the virus from the children, or of the children passing it on to each other.That way, we can have ironed out the glitches and be ready in September to be absolutely on the ball. Small group tutoring for recovery programmes, mentoring not just organised centrally, but co-ordinated locally.For anyone who doesn’t believe that two or three weeks matter in terms of education, when children have been out of school since the middle of March, then think again. This is about equality, narrowing the gap between the haves and have-nots, and opening a window on the world. But it is also more than that. It’s a place of social interaction, of well-being and of safety. Don’t take my word for it. Take the word of the Royal College of Paediatricians, the people whose whole le is spent on the well-being of children. They are very clear: Schools must , children need each other as well as their teachers.The recognition of the importance of schools was something I was proud to oversee in , when the incoming government’s priority slogan was, “education, education, education”.Don’t get me wrong. The belated announcement last week of a one per cent uplt for all schools and a £million pot for an online recovery programme is extremely welcome. A pity, therefore, that in making a really great announcement, the Government managed not to put any money aside for the  to -year-olds in further education, who are surely the target group we would want to be helping the most.So, thank you to all those who have done everything they can to keep the wheels on the cart over the past dficult three and a half months. But now we need both national leadership and local organisation. To use an old adage, we need to think national but we need to act local. Education trusts, local authorities, teachers’ unions and all those committed to the future of this nation should want to come together to make it work.In the next ten days, while the Government thinks about its advice, others can get on with the job. Take what is working best and spread it.What can work in France or Denmark or Germany can certainly work here. We are not out of the woods yet, but we can take logical, rational and brave decisions. That is what leadership is all about.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry shaped hole happy royal family
story: To the rest of us, it’s a charming exception to the more formal royal photos of old.But how was it received by the person who’s so obviously missing from this image of paternal closeness . . .  Prince Harry Since a spokesman confirmed that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex would be inactive on their @sussexroyal Instagram account from Aprilthere’s no way of knowing whether Harry would have publicly thanked his father last Sunday or , indeed, he has done so in private.But given that he’s reportedly homesick for the UK, this photo — taken in December — must have prompted a visceral longing for home. How could it not The sense of countryside and fresh air it evokes, the tweed caps, the fingerless mittens, the ornate walking stick . . .  just the innate Britishness of it all. Such a far cry from the smog, red carpets, bling and supercars of LA.And then, of course, it’s a reminder of the people he’s known since birth.Those who, unlike the “mwah mwah”, showbiz crowd, love him for who, rather than what, he is.Whichever way you view his behaviour of late, it’s undeniable that there is a huge, Harry-shaped hole in this image of family togetherness.Of course, there are Zoom meetings to be had and, post-lockdown, the occasional visit to be made. But it’s never quite the same.And therein lies the rub when you marry someone from another country.At first your initial attraction and then love for each other transcends geographical or cultural dferences.But when children come along and you’re required to stay in one place, inevitably one of you has to give up more than the other.Meghan tried it, albeit for a very short time, and now Harry is the one living thousands of miles away from his family and the only le he’s ever known.He made the decision to step down as a senior royal and decamp to the US for the sake of his new family — Meghan and Archie — but that doesn’t make it any less tough to see the old one ticking over nicely without him.A couple of years ago, I was in a central London restaurant with a group of other married couples and, much to the annoyance of we wives, the husbands couldn’t take their eyes off a woman sitting at the bar.Wearing the shortest of dresses, her legs were encircled around the object of her affections and her tongue made frequent visits to his ear.I recognised the man as actor Stephen Campbell Moore, ex-husband of The Crown star Claire Foy, and his obviously smitten companion as Sophie Cookson, who played Christine Keeler in last year’s BBC drama about the Profumo scandal.Fast forward to lockdown and this photo, suggests the couple may now be expecting their first child.The fond arrival of which will mean a heavy-hearted goodbye to those late-night, lust-filled liaisons that had the rest of us drooling with envy.Kaiser Chiefs frontman Ricky Wilson says he amuses himself by lying in interviews then changing his Wikipedia page to match his inventions.It reminds me of my stint as a royal correspondent when, after days of being on the road together, we would challenge each other to use silly names in stories.Hence, “Toby Lerone” was quoted in an article filed from the royals’ favourite ski resort in Switzerland, and in another story to do with Italy, “Sam Buca” made an appearance.Daft, I know, but it amused usno one .Mr Pendragon, who refuses to pay to park, says they stopped him from leaving his car on nearby roads.Shouldn’t he have been on horseback Bored by St Tropez, billionaires are reportedly snapping up “expedition yachts” that will take them to more adventurous corners of the globe.The one owned by US billionaire Ray Dalio has three deep-ing submersibles, and converted former Soviet spy boat Olivia is currently on the market for £million.Back home, lock-down quarantine rules have forced a  per cent rise in multi-millionaire Brits splashing their cash on vast private pools.Meanwhile, the rest of us will make do with a boat in the bath and a paddling pool.Sarah Ferguson – aka Prince Andrew’s ex we – is building up quite a following on her YouTube channel, where she reads children’s books such as The Wonky Donkey and Little Red Riding Hood while wearing fancy dress.Her success is no surprise, because on the many occasions I’ve seen her at charity events, she always connects brilliantly with the children in attendance.But personally, I can’t wait for her to get round to the critically acclaimed Idan Hadari book about a boy who wants to be famous.It’s called Andrew’s Claim To Fame.Or, in the Duke of York’s case, should that be infamy Yep. She now looks about .When -year-old Khairi Saadallah started his alleged kne rampage in a Reading park, a young, off-duty police officer ran towards the danger and rugby tackled him to the ground.It was a selfless act of bravery that, according to sources, saved “many more people dying”.Meanwhile, a judge has praised the bravery of PC Andrew Harper, who died after being dragged along by a car as he chased some thieves.Both of these are salutary reminders that, while every police force in the world has a few bad apples, the majority of those working in law enforcement are undeniably courageous people doing a tough job that most of us would shy away from.The latest money-making exercise candle from Gwyneth Paltrow is called This Smells Like My Orgasm.Which, as you ask, is “tart grapefruit, neroli, and ripe cassis berries blended with gunpowder tea and Turkish rose absolutes”. Er, right.Like its highly successful predecessor This Smells Like My Vagina candle – which, for the blissfully unaware, is “geranium, citrusy bergamot, and cedar absolutes juxtaposed with Damask rose and ambrette seed” – it costs£.Clearly, she’s a sales genius who could flog underwear to a nudist, but one suspects any attempt to branch out with a, to put it politely, Smells Like My Winkle range might prove a tougher sell.Hmmm. While the new name — Lost The Pot Noodle — is inspired, one notes that it now requires the consumer to put the ingredients in a mug or make it in a pan on the stove.As any self-respecting, Olympically idle student will tell you, a clean mug is a rarer sighting than an eclipse and, as for a pan, eventhey own one it will be housing enough penicillin growth to solve America’s recent shortage.So, memo to Unilever: Don’t phase out the original just yet.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: stay half in half out of lockdown well be happier
story: LOCKDOWN is pretty much over. The Prime Minister announced that we were at last allowed out of our Great British Hibernation.We can go to the pub, buy useless tat in shops and queue up for plaster lawn ornaments from garden centres. We can have the in-laws round to visit! Yoot!⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBoris says that his decision was made on good scientic advice. Hmm, maybe. It is true that the infection rate for Covid has been dropping rapidly for some time. But it’s still there, still hanging around with mischief on its mind. All it takes is one person in a gathering of  or  at some pizza joint and that infection rate will be up again quickly enough.In some of the countries that have released their people from lockdown, a second spike has occurred.In Germany the famous “R” rate for infection is well above the dreaded one. South Korea and Spain have seen new outbreaks, too.But the truth is Boris didn’t have much of an option. The public is bored stf and the economy is wrecked.I suspect the decision was arrived at on those grounds, rather than strictly on the science. Everyone wants to go out and spend money. I am not sure why they do.  There were good things about lockdown — and it taught us one or two truths about ourselves.It was a pleasure to hear the birds singing, for example. A real delight to see the roads free from traffic. The skies are full of swts and swallows instead of the incessant airline flights. The quality of the air we breathe improved hugely as a result. So did the water quality of rivers and streams.We went out much, much less. As a consequence, many people saved an awful lot of money because they weren’t wasting it on buying rubbish from shops.People learned to cook — and ate home-prepared meals with their families. The truth is, in normal times, we eat out far more often than is good for us, financially or otherwise. And we shopped locally — the corner stores did a roaring trade — and less often, thus saving carbon emissions.Employers discovered that people could work from home perfectly well. Hopefully this will persuade some to scale back their offices and give people the chance to work from home.Imagine how many homes could be created from disused offices! We wouldn’t have to pave over half the country to sort out our housing crisis. Imagine cutting out the daily commute for ever!We didn’t have to hug people. Indeed, we were barred by law from hugging people. Or kissing them on the bloody cheek, like everyone in the media world does. That, by itself, was a huge bonus for me.My wish is that we take some of that stuff from lockdown and make it the new normal. Live at a quieter, gentler pace. Continue to eat at home — and support our local corner shops. Use the car less. Spend less money on a whole load of b******s we don’t really need. Use aeroplanes not at all, preferably. Right now, the Government has given us licence to go out and do stuff.Here’s my plea. Let’s do a bit less stuff than we used to. Let’s remain kind of half in and half out of lockdown. Whether Covid is still around or not. We’ll end up happier as a result.ONE thing Captain Tom showed us, as he walked around his garden as he approached the age of , is that it’s never too late to make a dference.Bob Dylan is just a young whippersnapper by Tom’s standards.But at the age of  he has just made his finest album in at least three decades, and probably more. Rough And Rowdy Ways is a joy to listen to – and I’d given up on the bloke in the s.If I ever reach  I intend to make a grime album with Rihanna. Get your orders in now.The United Nations has decided to give them to Mauritius. That’s because the islands are nearer Mauritius than they are to the UK. On that basis we could have a good claim to owning Belgium. The islands are important to the UK militarily. And we should keep them. The UN has given us deadlines to hand them over to a country that never owned them. What we should do instead is leave the crooked UN.EXCLUDED from the Government’s loosening of lockdown are Britain’s vibrant community of werewolves and vampires.“It is all very well biting someone’s neck, or ripping their lungs out while howling loudly,” a scientist advising the Government probably said. “But when they do this there is the risk that the virus could be passed on via droplets from the creature’s mouth. Or indeed paws – werewolves do not have a good record of using hand-sanitiser.”By contrast, zombies were praised for their social-distancing technique. “Whenever you see them they are always walking two metres apart with their hands outstretched and bits of flesh falling off their faces,” the same scientist probably added.A spokesman for the National Association of Lycanthropescommented: “This is typical of the prejudice we werewolves face and amounts to discrimination. Actually, I thought I had the virus a few weeks ago. Nasty cough and so on.“But I’m all right nooooowwwwwwooooo.”THE day after the woke ninnies at Warners withdrew the great Hollywood film Gone With The Wind because of “race issues”, guess what happened  Yup, it became the No bestselling film on Amazon. Better still, it reached No in the AppleiTunes chart for TV and film. Not bad for a movie made more than  years ago, huh I suppose it could have been “progressives” buying the film so that they would have something to be outraged about. Or maybe the Ku Klux Klan Film Club has a bigger membership than we thought.More likely though is that people loathe censorship. They don’t like being told what they can and can’t watch. Truth be told it hasn’t been for a good  years. And the process accelerated under Magic Grandpa and his front bench of mouth-breathing dingbats. Now it’s the well-orf who support Labour. And the poor who vote Conservative. But there aren’t enough people called Olly and Poppy in the country, which is why Labour hasn’t won an election for  years. Unless it reconnects with the people it was set up to support, the working class, it won’t win one for another few decades either.A SOCIAL media site had a big hit when it asked people to reveal things they regretted about getting married. The site, Whisper, was inundated with replies. Most were kind of: “I just wish I hadn’t married the fat bastard, full stop.”But some wished they’d had a fling with someone of the same sex first, or felt aggrieved they hadn’t checked out the in-laws first. That was quite a big issue. title: music britain collapsing covid 19
story: And now I’m scratching my head wondering how cinemas are able to welcome visitors before we’ve worked out how to listen to music together.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesLive music is vital, not just for fuelling our dreams but for the reality of our economy, too.The live music sector is expecting to suffer £million in losses this year, which is  per cent of its annual contribution to the UK economy.From arena concerts to your local pub singer, ALL live music has been silenced.But the Government doesn’t seem to be taking it seriously, with music way down the list of priorities and no date in the diary for when we will be able to go to a gig again.We can’t afford to take our music scene for granted.Since the birth of rock ’n’ roll, Britain has dominated global tastes in pop music.Part of The Beatles’ legacy is that they transformed the British record business from a cottage industry into a global phenomenon.When they signed to Parlophone, early in the Sixties, one man and his secretary ran the entire label.George Martin signed the band, produced, manufactured and promoted their early records and, over the brief course of the band’s existence, saw the whole thing go through the roof.It was comparable to the dotcom boom or internet shopping.Many now see the Rolling Stones as the greatest band to come out of that era for the way they have managed to continue playing to vast new audiences  years later.But the Sixties was just the start of it. The Seventies brought Led Zeppelin and countless rock bands, it gave us heavy metal and punk and Joy Division pretty much all at the same time.The biggest-selling album of the Eighties, Michael Jackson’s Thriller, was actually written by a bloke from Hull, while British greats as erse as Duran Duran and The Smiths ruled the waves.In the Cool Britannia of the Nineties, when Britpop was ringing out of radio networks worldwide, even American stars such as Madonna sought help from British producers such as Nellee Hooper and William Orbit.Then there were the Spice Girls. And Coldplay. Now we’ve got Ed Sheeran and Adele. And it doesn’t stop with artists. Love him or hate him, Simon Cowell’s TV programmes are another British global music phenomenon.But it’s live music where Britain really dominates today. Glastonbury should be taking place this weekend.I’ve played at just about every major festival on the planet, from Coachella in the US to Fuji Rock in Japan, but there is nowhere to touch Glastonbury.It is, quite simply, the greatest show on earth There is a massive ripple effect from Glastonbury. It sets a very high bar for the other  — that’s  — festivals that happen throughout the UK every single summer.And the same crews who build the stages, operate the sound systems, put up the fences and supply the bogs for Glasto are busy for the rest of the summer at other events.Now the independent festival sector is at risk of collapse thanks to the Covid shutdown.Last month, the Association of Independent Festivals , which represents  festivals in the UK, reported that  per cent of its members were facing costs that could ruin their businesses and . per cent were uninsured for Covid- related cancellations.Most of my time these days is spent planning and organising The Big Feastival, which was due to take place here on my farm in Oxfordshire this August Bank Holiday weekend.Of course I’m devastated it won’t be going ahead, but the really sad thing is that it looks like no one is going to hear any live music, new or old this summer.That’s a tragedy for the musicians who rely on gigging to make a living — as well as all the other people whose income relies on live music.The Musicians’ Union says its members have lost more than £million in income during the lockdown. Remember, that most musicians just scrape by at the best of times.Big stars are bigger than ever before, but they are the exception not the rule. When Adele releases another record there is a danger she will become so massive she will collapse into a black hole.But now bands need an audience to play to and also financial support, which used to come from record companies but now is hard to find.Records, or downloads, are basically free these days, so live shows are the only real way to make money.In the same way restaurants were already struggling before lockdown, many of Britain’s smaller live music venues were struggling too.So most of the places I played in the early days with Blur have already dis- appeared. They need to be able to open their doors again, as do festivals.It has to be possible to find a way. Just as with pubs, restaurants and cinemas, you could limit the number of people allowed into a venue.Perhaps more gigs could be seated to ensure social distancing. Not quite the same, but better than nothing.As far as the rest of the planet is concerned, Britain is represented pretty much by the Royal Family, football and music.We must keep our festival circuit alive and nurture new artists.That means we urgently have to find a way for music to be played to a live audience, evenit’s only a small one — so that we can keep meaning something to the rest of the world.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: unions betrayed our kids
story: Its Headmaster Ben Hulme used his imagination, created extra space on the school field and put other hygiene measures in place.Now, to the delight of parents, almost all his pupils started back on Monday. And that’s with the two-metre rule.Yes, it’s easier with a small school. But his determination to do what is right by the children made the real dference.Contrast that with the union militants and council leaders of the Left. Although the Government could have done better in prioritising education, the wrecking crew have revelled in  confronting and defying the Tories, blocking efforts to reopen fully.Even now, the PM’s announcement that schools must open in September is branded “pure fantasy” by one union.We do not yet know the true cost to our children’s education, le chances and health from this failure of will. The unions have betrayed our kids and tarnished the image of the teachers they represent and who would love to get back to the classroom.PUBS with no music, singing, dancing or shouting  That’s just a library with more beer and no books.And how about visor-clad hairdressers snipping in enforced silence, with no gossip or radio It all sounds like a sci-fi dystopia of Britain. But this is the Government’s vision for our summer as it tries to save businesses while keeping us safe.To which we say: Well, good luck with that. We understand the reasoning. The scientists say all these activities pass on Covid in the breath. And they are desperate to avoid a new surge in cases.Some might see little point in a pub with the le sucked out of it. But we must use them or lose them.From July , support your local. Consider it your solemn duty.THE survey saying a quarter of furloughed workers will lose their jobs is horrying.Nine million are being kept afloat by the bailout. But that ruinous cost will end. At which point more than two million will be added to the dole queue.That will be a bitter blow for many who have enjoyed the lockdown — some packing the beaches yesterday on what would ordinarily be a working day.The bailouts’ end in October spells devastation in particular for the young and low-paid. And it falls to Chancellor Rishi Sunak to recreate the jobs boom of the last decade.At least, post-Brexit, he will have even more tools with which to do it.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: monkeys apes thailand lopburi
story: Locals in the city of Lopburi say the macaques primates are running rampant because the lack of tourism caused by the coronavirus lockdown has left the feral beasts starved of food.Residents have tried to help the creatures by feeding them junk food, but it is feared the sugary diet has made them sex crazed and breeding faster than before, it has been reported.Now, a sterilisation plan by authorities is underway as locals look to take back control of the streets.Before coronavirus, the humans and the primates used to live together peacefully with the monkey population believed to be as high as ,.But since the regular food supply from tourists dried up and the streets emptied, locals talk of a city where the small creatures are running riot. Local woman Kuljira Taechawattanawanna told the Daily Mail it was like being in prison: We live in a cage but the monkeys live outside.Despite the animals being outnumbered by the , humans living there, parts of the city are said to now be no-go zones. According to witnesses, the animals have turned an abandoned cinema into their headquarters where they also leave the remains of their dead love ones.Any human who attempts to enter is reportedly attacked.Residents had resorted to giving the monkeys sweets, fizzy drinks and cereal - but now fear the sugary treats have made them more hyper and sexually-active.Drastic action is now being taken by authorities who have restarted a sterilisation this month after a three-year pause. Wildle department officers plan to lure the creatures into cages and take them to a clinic, where they will be sedated, sterilised and left with a tattoo to mark their neutering. They aim to neuter  of them by Friday.It is thought there may be some pushback from residents who have grown accustomed to the monkeys, despite the problems they have caused recently. Taweesak Srisaguan, a shop owner who uses stuffed toy animals to try and scare the horde away, is wary of them disappearing completely. He said: Im used to seeing them walking around, playing on the street.If theyre all gone, Id definitely be lonely.Narongporn Daudduem from the wildle department acknowledges locals will have to give their consent. We need to do a survey of the people living in the area first.Its like dumping garbage in front of their houses and asking themtheyre happy or not.The primate presence in Lopburi previously came under the spotlight in March when a mass brawl over a single banana went viral. title: hero teen odney weir
story: Jack Staunton and Ralph Sewell, both , ed into the water at the beauty spot to help the swimmer after he failed to resurface. The brave teenagers had been relaxing with a group of friends at Odney Weir, in Cookham, Berks., on Tuesday when the tragedy hit. The body of dad-of-five Eyad Al Ryabi, who is also believed to have jumped in to try to save his friend, was found by emergency service teams at the scene on Wednesday. His friend, in his s, who has not been named, was rushed to hospital where he remains in a serious condition. Eyad moved to the UK from Syria towards the end of last year to try to make a better le for his family, his relative said.Both boys describe seeing a group of men jumping into deep parts of the water in jeans and t-shirts. Jack, from Maidenhead, told The Sun: “They were part of this big group, all swimming and messing around like we were. “One of them jumped over the Weir, and got sucked in. We are pretty sure he was knocked unconscious under the water and he didn’t come back up again. “Ralph and I saw what was happening and we climbed over and started trying to pull him out. “His friend also climbed over and tried to pull him out, he was unconscious. “We were telling them to pull his head out of the water, and Ralph was trying to do that and had a hold of him and was swimming alongside him. “His friend then lost his grip on him and he started getting pushed down the river because of the current. “A fisherman jumped in and helped us to grab him and pull him out to put him on the side of the river. “That was when someone  started to perform CPR on him, the ambulance service were telling them what to do on the phone. “I tried to do CPR but I wasn’t strong enough so I asked for help. “After all of this another one of his friends had tried to save him by grabbing the leguard ring and ing in. “We were all focusing on the first man we didn’t realise the second one had been swept away.“Because my friends and I go there quite a lot we know to avoid the middle of the river because of the hotspots. “But these guys didn’t know where they shouldn’t jump and got sucked into the current.“I’ve been going there for a long time and nothing like this has ever happened before.”Ralph added: “A group of us were at the weir and suddenly I heard the guys screaming, three of them were in the water and one was unconscious. “They were trying to get him out, and when I heard the screaming I jumped in and climbed down the weir and tried to help them pull him out. “His head was really under the water, his friend seemed to lose his grip on him and he went even further under the water. “As he went down the river someone helped us to get him on the bank and then an older guy performed CPR on him. “I’m glad he’s alive, I know he’s in the hospital but I hope he is okay. There was a lot going on at that moment. “The part that they jumped into was probably the most dangerous part of the weir, we did try to find his friend but we didn’t want to risk it when we know what the currents are like. “It’s generally a pretty safe place to go and swim but I don’t think we will be going back there again.”Both boys jumped back in to try to save Syrian refugee Eyad after he had also tried to save his pal. Other members of the Syrian community in West London also travelled to the riverbank after learning their friend, , who lives in Uxbridge, had gone missing.Jacks mum Nicola Thomas said: “It’s heartbreaking for the boys to see all of this, and for the family of the man that it’s happened to. “I didn’t know whether to shout at Jack or hug him at first, because he’s put himself in danger jumping in but I am proud of him. “They definitely saved his le, there is no doubt about that.”The tragedy came as temperatures soared to around C on Tuesday as Britains heatwave continues.Officials from the Royal Berkshire Fire and Rescue Service said crews were at the riverside for almost three-and-a-half hours.A spokesman said: We are urging residents across Berkshire to take care near water.As the warm weather continues, it may be tempting to swim in open water, but there are many dangers involved.One of the main risks when entering the water is cold water shock, eventhe weather is warm.You also do not know what is beneath the surface – there could be unseen currents and reeds, which could pull you under.”LPA Commander for Windsor  Maidenhead, Superintendent Colin Hudson, said: “Officers have been working tirelessly with our partners to locate the man who entered the water yesterday, and have now tragically found a body.“We are grateful for the support we received from both Berkshire and Buckinghamshire Fire and Rescue Services, South Central Ambulance Service, and Berkshire Lowland Search and Rescue.“I would also like to thank members of the public who provided information as well as assistance to my officers.“I would like to thank them for their patience while officers investigated this incident, and we will be leaving the scene shortly.“I am very sorry to have to bring this sad news.“Our thoughts are with both men’s families during this very upsetting time.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur title: ikea bookcase topple over children california
story: A baby camera in Nicole Oka’s home in Calornia captured what happened to the two-year-olds on June .The video shows the twins climbing on the bookcase in their bedroom after being put to bed.Soon, the bookcase can be seen crashing down on them — despite Oka believing the dresser was screwed into the wall.The kids are heard screaming and soon, the children’s parents rush in to get them.Oka told USA Today: “I remember being so afraid of this happening. It felt like a very real thing that could happen to me.”“My babies could have died,” the mother said. “I did everything right. I did everything I should have.”Oka toldwhat happened was “traumatic” and said she ran to the children as soon as what saw the incident on the baby camera.The mother and her husband, Dan, bought the bookcase in  and said they understood it could be a potential hazard — so they bought brackets to keep it flat against the wall.Ikea spokesperson Hanna Bengtsander said in a statement that the company was investigating what happened.“We are currently reviewing the video involving the Brimnes bookcase and need more time to get a better understanding of the details,” she said, adding they couldn’t provide further comment at the time.According to USA Today, at least  children have died from furniture tip-over accidents since .Ikea dressers specically have caused at least five deaths since , per the report.In , Ikea recalled .million dressers that didn’t meet the required safety standards, and acknowledged the fact.• February : A -month-old boy from Apple Valley, Minn. died after an unanchored MALM -drawer chest fell on top of him.• July : A -month-old girl from Mount Vernon, Virginia, died after an unanchored Gute -drawer chest tipped over and pinned her against the footboard of a youth bed.In , Ikea sold another dresser that didn’t meet the voluntary stability standard for  weeks before it was recalled in March.The dresser that fell on the twins earlier this month, according to USA Today, was recalled in .The Brimnes bookshelf was over six feet high and included two drawers at the bottom, with four shelves.In January, Ikea agreed to pay million to the parents of Jozef Dudek, a two-year-old boy who died in  after a -pounds recalled dresser tipped over onto him.The boy died of his injuries and his parents sued Ikea, accusing the Swedish company of knowing the specic dresser posed a hazard, but that the company failed to warn consumers about it.The Dudek family said they would donate million from the settlement to organizations that advocate for more rigorous stability testing for dressers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: man battered by gang boozy teens
story: The -year-old was rushed to hospital with a broken leg yesterday evening and is in a stable condition after the horrendous attack.Four boys aged - had been drinking and were arrested by cops, who arrived within minutes of being called to the field off Bateman Avenue, Greater Manchester.A large group of teenagers had also been in the field before being told to leave by a member of the public, according to Greater Manchester Police.Territorial Commander Chief Superintendent Chris Allsop said: “A local man was subjected to a horrendous attack by a group of teenagers after he asked them to move from private property.He encouraged anyone with information or footage to reach out and added: “The risk of coronavirus is still present and attending these events is putting you at risk. title: west end stars should give back
story: I BELIEVE Boris Johnson when he says the thing he is looking forward to most as we emerge from our enforced national hibernation is taking in some Shakespeare at the Globe theatre.Butthe Prime Minister is not careful that’s an option that might not be available to him.I’m less of a culture vulture when it comes to high arts, but my heart aches to go to one of my beloved West End musicals. I mean, I’ve only been able to see Dear Evan Hansen  times so far.And Christmas won’t be the same without the uniquely British tradition of the winter panto. How will all those former boyband stars fund their showbiz lestyles for another year Sadly, post-Covid restrictions look particularly cruel to the arts.Those dastardly droplets mean singing is banned and the idea of packing out a historic theatre where the tiny seats mean you are virtually sitting on top of your neighbour just won’t cut it.But in the middle of an international health emergency it’s all too easy to dismiss the importance of stage shows, movies, the TV industry, festivals and concerts.The attitude seems to be: “We’re dying, goddammit, the economy is cratering, don’t talk to me about the bloody theatre!”But that approach will mean Britain is cakewalking into a cultural catastrophe that could wipe off decades of creative progress, end our modern domination of the arts and entertainment and see the closure of most historic theatres before the end of the year.If that is yet another horrid consequence of Covid-, a disease most likely spread because of a despicable Chinese wet market, I will be fuming.Dame Judi Denchs warning that theatres may not open again in her letime is as stark as it is horrying.It would wipe out £.billion of annual ticket sales, see , good folk lose their jobs and damage tourism.While the pressure is building by the day on the Government to launch yet another unprecedented rescue package, I think that’s only part of the answer.Entertainment is a big-money industry dominated by super-wealthy moguls who have a responsibility to look after as many of their loyal staff and young creatives as humanly possible.Now is the time for other celebrities and businesspeople who have earned a small fortune from the creative industries to give back.Where are all those Hollywood stars, with hundreds of millions in the bank, who rush to perform on the West End stage to be seen as a real actor, dahling Surely they could donate a tiny portion of their wealth to set up a private rescue fund for theatres For example, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, the South Park creators who are behind The Book Of Mormon, are worth a billion bucks.JK Rowling, whose Harry Potter play The Cursed Child is at the Palace Theatre, has a £million fortune.We Will Rock You producer Robert de Niro has £million in the bank, Sister Act producer and star Whoopi Goldberg £million, and West End favourite Dame Helen Mirren £million.I could name a hundred other multi-millionaire stars who have used the West End to enhance their careers who owe it to the backroom staff on the breadline to be part of the solution.Thankfully, the king of theatre — Lord Lloyd-Webber — has, as ever, proved inspirational and innovative.Without being asked, he is putting his money where his mouth is to PROVE to the Government that it is possible to safely reopen theatres WITHOUT ANY social distancing by using enhanced precautions such as temperature checks on the door and face masks for all audience members.The Government must listen to him and embrace his case study of Phantom Of The Opera, which has remained open in South Korea throughout the pandemic with no issues.Otherwise, we risk the curtain coming down for good.BACKING down so quickly on extending Sunday trading hours was a disappointing move forced by Tory backbenchers.While on first glance the idea of allowing supermarkets and other shops to stay open longer on our day of rest sounds unappealing to many workers, the reality is that this change would have probably saved many jobs in the long run.It’s nonsensical that on one day of the week most Tescos can only open for six hours, while international delivery services such as Amazon continue to decimate their business, especially now with social-distancing measures making it even more unappealing to spend time lining up outside.By contrast, the other night I was able to order an Amazon Prime Now delivery to arrive at my house at pm on a Sunday night.I’d ordered an Uber Eats takeaway from McDonald’s two hours earlier.The archaic current trading hours laws were introduced in , the year Jeff Bezos created a fledgling online book store called Amazon.Like it or not, that business has created a dferent world of consumerism.Compromises to allow workers the option not to take on more Sunday work, leaving the additional hours to those who want to earn extra cash, could make the necessary move more palatable.But let’s not avoid having the debate.THE Culture Secretary has so much on his plate that Shirley Ballas used an innovative approach to attract his attention this week – and it worked.Launching an impassioned plea to Oliver Dowden to “safely open” ballroom dance studios on my talkRADIO Drivetime show, the Strictly Come Dancing judge teased: “If Oliver is out there, I don’t even mind having a cha-cha-cha with him to show him it is possible to social distance.”Clearly the power of the Queen of Latin remains undiminished.Within hours, Oliver had tweeted: “Shirley, as a Strictly fan, I’m happy to talk about how we can get dancing going safely again. Great offer on the cha-cha-cha – I’ll get practising.”Expect dance studios to be back in business imminently, then.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
