story: TV presenter and naturalist Chris Packham praised the colourful planting surrounding the townrsquos iconic golf ball sculpture at the Levenhall roundabout, which contains a mix of Scottish wildflowers.Species include yarrow, cornflower, wild carrot, viperrsquos bugloss, corn marigold, hawkbit, ox-eye daisy, corn poppy, cowslip, primrose, meadow buttercup, yellow rattle, hedge woundwort, devilrsquos-bit scabious and dandelion.Referring to a video of the display on social media, Mr Packham, the co-presenter of the BBCrsquos nature programmes Springwatch, Autumnwatch and Winterwatch, tweeted: ldquoEvery council across the UK should aspire to this ndash itrsquos beautul and productive and what people want from a new normal for wildle and the environment. Top work Musselburgh!An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoIn recent years, East Lothian Council has created and managed a number of wildflower sites across the county to increase bioersity within towns and villages.ldquoThe wildflowers currently visible at the roundabout on Haddington Road, Musselburgh, have self-seeded from previous yearsrsquo sowing and have been appreciated for their colourful display by both local residents and visitors.ldquoSome of the wildflower sites in East Lothian form part of the John Muir Pollinator Way, which aims to create habitat for pollinators along the entire -mile route of the John Muir Way.ldquoThis initiative, developed by Bugle UK, identies where wildflower forage and nesting habitats for pollinators and other wildle can be created, enhanced and managed along the John Muir Way, including on school grounds, golf courses, cemeteries and public parks, and included wildflower sowing at Prestongrange Museum last year.Irene Tait, chairperson of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, said: ldquoIt is stunning and has really taken off this year. Anything which involves wildflowers is gorgeous.The golf ball-shaped sphere, made of hundreds of horse shoes, is one of two sporting sculptures commissioned by the community council for the townrsquos gateways, depicting the townrsquos golf and horse racing heritage. Sculptor Ronnie Elliot designed the golf ball, while artist Kenny Munro created a steel sculpture of three race horses at Newhailes.

title: former-mens-club-become-four-flats
story: East Lothian Council has given the green light to East Lothian Propertyrsquos plans to transform  Sidegate.The former Haddington Recreation Club closed its doors in the early s and will now become home to a ground-floor office and four flats.The three-storey property is currently used as bedsit accommodation.One member of the public objected to the proposals on grounds including road safety, the likelihood that ldquothe use of the building to accommodate an office and four flats will lead to a large number of cars parking on street at this potentially dangerous spot and that the proposals ldquodo not accommodate any dedicated off-street parking, the consequence of which would result in cars being parked on the narrow road outside the building which would result in dficulties for other road users and would create a road safety hazard.Despite the objections, the plans were given the go ahead, with the planning officer noting that colleagues in the roads services department raised ldquono objection to the plans.Billiards, draughts and table tennis were all played by male members of Haddington Recreation Club before it closed. It also had a licensed bar.

title: man-stamps-mark-unique-present-idea
story: Donald Malone ndash originally from Whittingehame and who runs his own wildle education business, Wildside Nature ndash is using stamps from all over the world in a iety of dferent ways as interesting gt ideas for people.He explained: ldquoI collected stamps when I was a child, aged seven or eight.ldquoThen about  years ago my interest in them restarted. I would pick them upI found albums or packets in second hand shops.ldquoThese days I have hundreds of thousands. Friends will often hand me collections that their parents or they collected when they were young.ldquoOne friend gave me three boxes of stamps that he had seen in his motherrsquos house.ldquoEven when my we and I bought the house we are in now, the couple who were living there before handed old stamp albums to us a moving in present.He added: ldquoI either make up a compilation on a specic topic or country.ldquoSometimes I will just scan and blow up a single stamp, and I have put these on mugs and done screen prints of them on t-shirts and tote bags.ldquoI have previously made up orders on request, including one as a birthday present for someone who was from Zimbabwe, and have also done requests for cats, dogs and boats, to mention a few subjects.ldquoI have made one up as a wedding present, with stamps covering dferent aspects of the couple, where they met, got engaged, occupations and such like.Mr Malone, a former pupil at Stenton Primary and Dunbar Grammar School, has had his items stocked in a few shops in Edinburgh, where he now lives, and is keen to expand this to shops in East Lothian.He has also run sessions about stamps with ious organisations, including people using the Marie Curie Hospice and a group run by the Cyrenians, which helps people at risk of becoming homeless, both based in Edinburgh.He explained: ldquoPart of what I do and can offer the groups is the soaking of stamps off envelopes, drying and sorting them into ious categories.ldquoI am happy to post out sets of stamps and mounts covering ious topicsanyone wanted to have a go at making up their own compilations.ldquoI thought it might be a nice activity for those in care homes during the current period. I and others have always found it a very mindful and rewarding activity.Debbie Hogarth, an occupational therapist at the Marie Curie Hospice, said: ldquoEveryone loved the stamp activity with Donald ndash it sparked a lot of memories and conversations. When yoursquore living with a terminal illness, it can seem for some people that your world becomes small and this was an impactful way for people to come out of themselves and hear about adventures and sights around the world.ldquoIt was therapeutic to look through the collection, or create a meaningful gt themselves for a loved one. We really appreciate Donald volunteering his time to visit us and share his wonderful collection and stories.For more information, go to facebook AndoArtEdinburgh or instagram andoartedinburgh

title: letter-pub-boss-defends-punters-accused-flouting-lockdown-restrictions
story: A busy parade of customers from nearby shops ndash including a paper shop and butcherrsquos ndash were, like me, doing essential food shopping yet many were elderly and had to squeeze perilously past boisterous drinkers outside the public house.Sitting in my car, watching with disbelief for  minutes, I felt for the many elderly folk forced to step onto the road ndash a road safety  coronavirus double jeopardy ndash to avoid increasingly boisterous and potentially Covid--infected drinkers, m social distancing clearly conveniently forgotten.With other pubs in East Lothian adhering to Scottish Government rules, I do wonder what commercial or social imperative The Seaglass licensees consider they enjoy and can be used to justy over and above other public houses in the county, some of whom could now be encouraged to follow suit.Potentially, for drinkers, a couple of pints in exchange for infecting each other or innocent pedestrians for the licensee, some money infor compromising the health and wellbeing of already vulnerable and compromised elderly shoppers, not to mention themselves, their staff and customers.Over recent months, Irsquove seen several incidences of domestic breaches of lockdown rules ndash including a close neighbour hosting a BBQ in her garden for a dozen or so family   friends ndash but Irsquom no vigilante or busybody, preferring to hope that iniduals voluntarily do their best to follow the rules, keeping themselves and others as safe as possible in precarious times.But for a publican to either flout ndash or bend ndash the rules, for commercial gain, creating a potential virus and road safety hotspot on a busy public thoroughfare to the benefit of nobody but themselves, whilst risking the health and wellbeing of others in the vicinity, takes irresponsibility to a dferent level.I went back on Sunday to seeSaturday might have been a one-off but it clearly wasnrsquot ndash as this image shows ndash but the crowd was approximately half of what it was on Saturday afternoon.Such selfish, reckless and morally unacceptable behaviour ndash quite possibly also illegal ndash flies in the face of the public interest, hence I would suggest the local constabulary call by The Seaglass for a quiet word ndash no more ndash in the licenseersquos ear to, as we say here in Scotland, lsquoscrew the nutrsquo.Name and address suppliedChristine OrsquoBrien, licensee of The Seaglass Inn, said in response to the comments: ldquoPubs in Scotland are allowed to offer a takeaway service during lockdown. The Seaglass Inn has not done so, with the exception of last weekend, when we sold takeaway beer in aid of the Port Seton Community Council resilience team, which is providing food and other essential support to those in need in the community during the Covid- crisis. Itrsquos an extremely valuable cause and one we wanted to back. The beer was sold in closed containers from a table at the entrance to the pub and customers were asked to move on once they had made their purchase. Two metre marks were put down on the pavement to help people queue at the appropriate distance and those serving wore masks and gloves and undertook regular cleaning and sanitisation of the table. The pub made no money from this fundraiser all proceeds are being donated to the resilience team. More than pound has been raised. We saw no boisterous behaviour from those who attended, so it is disappointing to hear these allegations to the contrary.

title: residents-dig-deep-christian-aid
story: Last year, groups of volunteers representing the charity in the county collected pound, during Christian Aid Week, which ran from May -.The money raised in  put the area at number  in the list of the UKrsquos  constituencies.This yearrsquos Christian Aid Week, which ran from May -, was slightly dferent due to the coronavirus pandemic.With volunteers unable to go door to door, the charity, which is the official relief and development agency of  Christian churches in the UK and Ireland, and works to support sustainable development, eradicate poverty, support civil society and provide disaster relief in South America, the Caribbean, Africa and Asia, took its campaign online.Aberlady and Gullane Parish Churches encouraged people to donate using the virtual lsquoe-envelopersquo which was shared with family and friends across the congregation.The Dunbar Christian Aid Group held an ecumenical service and raised over pound, via JustGiving.In Haddington, the Christian Aid Group raised more than pound, on their JustGiving page, which was also promoted and shared by St Maryrsquos Kirk on Facebook.Haddington West Church promoted an online quiz, while Dirleton Kirk and North Berwickrsquos Abbey Church hosted a family quiz night over Zoom.Sally Foster-Fulton, head of Christian Aid Scotland, said: ldquoIt was no surprise to us to find out that East Lothian is one of the most supportive parts of the UK.ldquoWe know just how active our supporters are there. Wersquore hugely grateful for our supportersrsquo efforts and creativity right across East Lothian.

title: money-set-aside-primary-school-improvements
story: A larger kitchen area is proposed in the first phase of the works, with two additional classrooms planned for the second phase.The proposals are being weighed up by East Lothian Council, although it is not known when any works,approved, could get under way due to the coronavirus.A spokeswoman for the local authority said the school community and headteacher would be kept up to date with any developments.A total of pound. million has been set aside for the works, which are required to accommodate the growing school population.She said: ldquoWorks at Aberlady Primary School would be undertaken in two phases, which is reflected in the planning applications that we have submitted.ldquoThe first phase involves internal configurations within the existing school to remove walls and create a larger kitchen area.ldquoNew landscaping will provide an accessible path to the front entrance to complement the red sandstone building and its position within a conservation area.ldquoThe second phase will involve the construction of a new building, connected to the existing school from the main hall.ldquoThis will provide a larger hall as well as two additional classrooms and ancillary break-out space.ldquoThe existing temporary unit, which currently houses a general classroom, will then be removed.ldquoAlternative access to the site will be created from a path beside the neighbouring sports pitches to preserve playground space as much as possible, and ensure works can continue safely.

title: students-party-teachers-dance-anthems-playlist
story: The Tranent schoolrsquos S students were due to attend their prom at Eskmills, Musselburgh on June , but were forced to change their plans due to the coronavirus.Rather than celebrating their final schooldays together in glitz and glamour, they were instead going to have to mark the end of school at home.However, one teacher did not want the day to go unnoticed and put together a playlist of teachersrsquo favourite dance floor anthems.Nicola Duncan, principal teacher of citizenship, said: ldquoI was out with my mum on a walk and said to her that I needed to do something for the sixth years, and give them a little something after their prom had to be postponed.ldquoMy mum said, lsquoWhat about a little playlist for them rsquo and I thought that it was a lovely idea.ldquoThey all enjoy listening to music and celebrating.ldquoI think everyone got something out of it, I just felt so sorry for them.After coming up with the idea, Miss Duncan sent an email to staff at Ross High and invited them to share online a couple of their favourite dance floor songs.All of the songs were added to a playlist on Spoty, which was later shared on Twitter with the message to the sixth years: ldquoThinking of you all today!! Until we can celebrate together have a boogie in your living rooms bedrooms to these.Miss Duncan, who also teaches history and modern studies, said: ldquoI think itrsquos nice, as yoursquove got music across all ages you have some older stuff and some current stuff in there, too.ldquoIt was nice to see them liking it and retweeting it.Some pupils put on the dresses and suits they were due to wear at the prom while they listened to the playlist at home.Lauren Burnett, of Carlaverock View, said: ldquoI decided to wear my dress as me and a couple of friends were a bit upset that it had been postponed, so we dressed up and had our own mini prom with just a couple of us.ldquoWe used some songs off the playlist as well as some of our own favourites.ldquoIt was quite fun to try and guess which teacher had added each song.ldquoI think the actual day we were meant to be at prom hit me the hardest as it was really awful not seeing my best friends, apart from through a screen.ldquoBut since then Irsquove kept myself busy with other work, and come to terms that itrsquos only postponed, and that prom will happen eventually.The -year-old, who hopes to study psychology and the classics at the University of St Andrews, admitted that she cried while listening to the playlist and thanked her teachers for making the playlist and for supporting the students.Ross High Schoolrsquos prom has been rescheduled for November and Miss Duncan said: ldquoWe still want it to go ahead and are going to try and do something like a leaving ceremony for them.To listen to the playlist go to open.spoty playlist dQVdihcCCqYILUnYV sipricmEfRPigRHRgrqsw

title: artist-explores-coronavirus-minefield
story: Georgina Bown is an award-winning artist and sculptor whose artwork focuses on nautical man-made constructions.She is well known for her work depicting submarines and oil rigs.After lockdown began in March, Georgina found herself isolated with her two children and confined to work at home.She used this time to create a huge charcoal and pastel drawing of sea mines.The work, named lsquoMinefieldrsquo and measuring cm by cm, took her eight days to complete.Georgina said: ldquoI began feeling that we are in an unpredictable lsquominefieldrsquo, dominated by this highly contagious threat.ldquoThis led me to research sea mines ndash not only are they similar to the virus in shape but can be triggered by physical contact, too.ldquoI hope my work will create a consciousness of this delicate situation and how human touch has become a precarious thing.Throughout the eight days it took her to complete the piece, Georgina filmed a time-lapse of herself at work.The video can be viewed on her Facebook page at www.facebook GeorginaBownArtist

title: chef-praises-student-food-initiative
story: Ms Leith, the universityrsquos chancellor, in her latest video to students and staff, praised those behind lsquoEmpty Kitchens, Full Heartsrsquo, which has distributed more than , meals during the Covid- lockdown to those in need around Edinburgh.The scheme was launched by Lewis McLachlan, an MSc gastronomy student, and involves chefs, students, hospitality business owners and suppliers volunteering to collect food donations and prepare free meal packs.Lewis said: ldquoWersquove built quite a nice community of volunteers and lsquoEmpty Kitchens, Full Heartsrsquo is helping us feel a sense of belonging and purpose, too.ldquoThese volunteers are people who wanted to get stuck in and help out. Irsquom so proud of each and every one of them.In her video, Ms Leith discusses healthy eating during lockdown and highlights the gastronomy studentsrsquo ldquoenterprise.She said: ldquoI am so pleased with the gastronomy students who have got together to form their little enterprise called lsquoEmpty Kitchens, Full Hearts.rsquoldquoWhat it does is feed people who are desperately in need of a decent meal and I know they will be bringing, not just nutrition, but genuine comfort and joy.She added: ldquoPlease eat properly yourselves. If you eat nothing but junk, you wonrsquot feel really well.ldquoSo try to eat as much fresh food as you can. I know itrsquos dficult to get but donrsquot just reach for the chocolate bars, Irsquom begging you.For more information, go to facebook EmptyKitchens FullHeartsTo view a video of Lewis talking about their hot lunches, go to facebook EmptyKitchensFullHearts videos

title: high-school-students-snap-photography-contest-top-prizes
story: Carla Mulholland and Declan Longmuir were celebrating some picture perfect images after being crowned winners in the Scottish Civic Trustrsquos My Place Photography competition.The national competition encourages budding photographers, aged between four and , to explore the buildings, architecture and archaeology in the places they live, and experiment with using photography as a means of investigation and creative expression.The competition has free entry, and is open to schools, youth groups, clubs and home-educated young people.The theme for submissions in  was water, in celebration of Scotlandrsquos Year of Coasts and Waters.Carla, , who is in S at the Prestonpans high school, was the overall winner in the secondary school category for her photograph lsquoAutumn Leavesrsquo.Saskia Hanmer, from Dunbar Grammar School, was highly commended for her picture, titled lsquoTime Delaysrsquo.Meanwhile, S pupil Declan Longmuir was also celebrating.The -year-old won the Young Personsrsquo Choice Award for his photograph lsquoChristmas at Port Seton Harbourrsquo.A spokesman for the school said: ldquoThis is a real achievement for PL, as our photography course is a short course, recently introduced to the curriculum.ldquoCongratulations to both pupils!Each year, winners of the My Place Photography Competition are honoured at a reception and their entries are displayed in a public exhibition.The  reception and exhibition launch, which was planned for April  at Glasgow Doors Open Days festival hub The Lighthouse, has been rescheduled for September this year.Fiona Hyslop MSP, cabinet secretary for economy, fair work and culture, said: ldquoI want to congratulate all of this yearrsquos entrants for the exceptional standard of photography that has again been produced by Scotlandrsquos schoolchildren for the My Place Photography Awards, and the many inventive ways in which they have captured their local built environments.ldquoThe awards are a terric way to stimulate interest and to nurture a concern for our surroundings from an early age, and itrsquos great that we can still enjoy seeing the world through the eyes of our young people, by way of the online gallery this year.

title: survey-reveals-public-support-active-travel
story: The survey found that, since the Covid- lockdown began in late March, many people have been cyclingor walkingfour to seven days a week, mainly for exercise or shopping.Equally, respondents to the survey, which was carried out by the Drem Gullane Path Campaign group, reported a marked drop in their use of private cars and public transport in lockdown.Iain Monk, spokesman for the campaign group, said: ldquoThe Covid- lockdown has seen many more people choosing to cycle and walk for exercise and essential journeys.ldquoThere seems to have been a fundamental sht in attitudes towards travel.ldquoAs our survey results show, because the roads are quieter, residents have been taking advantage of the safer environment.ldquoIt is also clear that people want to keep cycling or walking and expect more active travel choices.ldquoWe need council leaders to make a long-term commitment to invest in permanent infrastructure that will help people cycle and walk safely.Of the  people questioned, the vast majority expressed a desire to continue walkingand cyclingthe same, or even more, once lockdown restrictions are lted.Eighty nine per cent of people canvassed thought that East Lothian Council should signicantly invest more in cycling and walking infrastructure.Dominic Campanile, general manager of The Old Clubhouse bar and restaurant in Gullane, said: ldquoAs a local business, the Old Clubhouse is in no doubt about the positive economic impact of more cycling and walking infrastructure.ldquoThe Covid- lockdown has shown that people clearly want more active travel options.ldquoThat is why our business hopes East Lothian Council will look to the future and invest more in active travel infrastructure.A spokeswoman for the local authority stressed it ldquoremains committed to identying and securing active travel options in East Lothian, building upon previous projects.She said: ldquoWe have delivered a comprehensive path network across the county and, over the past five years, have committed capital funding to sustainable travel options, including the safe link from Gullane to North Berwick.ldquoWe are developing proposals for further projects around East Lothian, and having active travel at the core of local transport infrastructure will be a key priority going forward.ldquoWe are also preparing a bid for funding under the new infrastructure programme Spaces for People, which offers funding and support to councils in Scotland to make it safer for people to walk, cycle or wheel for essential trips and exercise during Covid- restrictions.

title: pipers-cook-storm-local-charity
story: Haddington Pipe Band has linked up with Our Community Kitchen, raising more than pound, to support the group, which is based in the townrsquos bowling club.Alastair Bruce, who is on the bandrsquos board of trustees, was delighted to help out in what were challenging circumstances for both organisations.He said: ldquoWe were obviously going to miss all the events that usually go on at this time of the year.ldquoWe came up with the idea of having performances in our gardens at the regular time of Saturday at noon and to keep playing and cheer folk up.ldquoWe started doing that and got a couple of weeks into it and were aware of what Our Community Kitchen were doing.ldquoWe wanted to support them and their fantastic work.The pipe band, which has been  and  members aged from nine to their s, would usually be performing at galas and civic celebrations throughout the county.However, the coronavirus has led to the cancellation of a number of those scheduled events, with weddings also being shelved due to the global pandemic.Mr Bruce said the pipe band decided to use their weekly performances as a fundraiser for Our Community Kitchen and set up an online fundraising page.An initial target of pound has been shattered, with the fundraising figure breaking through the pound, barrier.Mr Bruce thanked everyone that had donated to the cause and said: ldquoIt is wonderful.ldquoWe are really grateful to everybody that has helped with that.ldquoIt has not just been band members who have contributed but other people, who are aware of what the band are doing.ldquoOur Community Kitchen are really pleased as well and it helps them with their work as well.Our Community Kitchen was formed  months ago, with the aim of tackling social isolation in the Haddington and Lammermuir ward by getting people round the dinner table.However, the group was forced to change its method of addressing the problem when social gathering events were banned in March.Instead, they have delivered more than , piping hot meals, ranging from sausage, mash, stuffing and onion gravy to tuna macaroni and cheese, to people in their homes throughout Haddington during the lockdown period.Elaine Gale, founder of the group, who are delivering meals four times a week, was delighted with the pipe bandrsquos efforts and thanked them.She said: ldquoEvery Saturday, people play in their gardens or the street and where I live in Fairway, we have got two wonderful pipers and people donate.ldquoThey have raised more than pound,, which is unbelievable.ldquoWe are absolutely thrilled that they are doing that for Our Community Kitchen and we are doing our very best for the local community.ldquoIt is wonderful as well to hear them on a Saturday.ldquoI go out and listen to them and it just makes me feel really, really happy and quite tearful and emotional, to be honest.To support the pipe band and Our Community Kitchen, go to justgiving fundraising secretary-haddington-pipe-band

title: new-position-gives-cctv-dunbar-harbour-go-ahead
story: Dunbar Harbour Trustrsquos plans to mount two cameras on an eight-metre high pole at Lamer Island were originally rejected after East Lothian Councilrsquos planning officers ruled they would draw attention from the battery there.However, a second application has now been given the green light after the trust moved the location of the pole to the other side of a wall.The trust said the Lamer Island CCTV cameras, which have antennas, were required to link up a surveillance system with cameras already at the two harbours ndash Victoria and Cromwell ndash on either side of the battery.The original plan saw the pole placed at the front of Lamer Island. Now it will be installed beside the east wall of the battery.Officers approved an application for planning permission and one for listed building consent as required.The council officerrsquos report on the listed building application said: ldquoIn its location, the proposed pole, whilst visible, would not occupy such a prominent position in front of the battery as did the CCTV camera recently refused planning permission and listed building consent.ldquoInstead, it would be seen alongside and in relation to the east wall of the Lamer Island Battery which would provide some screening for the proposed pole.The Lamer Island Battery is an th-century lsquoD-planrsquo bastion of squared sandstone rubbleconstruction with pierced embrasure ornament openings, listed as being of specialarchitectural or historic interest, Category B.It was built as a civil defence outpost and hassubsequently had ious uses, including as an infectious diseases hospital in the th centuryand a military hospital during the First World War.Dunbar Harbour Trust has carried out work to bring the battery back to le and provide accessto it for all.It is currently in use as an interpretationbuilding and amphitheatre.The trust had applied for CCTV planning permission to ldquoaddress requests from the fishing community and generally improve safety and security coverage around the harbour.

title: baking-boys-boost-day-centre-funds
story: William and Alfie Pleasance took it upon themselves to hold a bake sale for the East Linton facility.Generous neighbours on the villagersquos Bank Road did their bit and bought the cakes, helping the duo raise pound.Lynton Day Centre had to temporarily shut its doors when lockdown restrictions were brought into place in March.Since then, staff at the day centre have provided a daily delivery service of a three-course meal to their clients and other vulnerable people in the village.A spokeswoman for the centre said: ldquoTo minimise the risk of spreading Covid- while delivering the meals, we have a strict infection control plan in place.ldquoThis involves using disposable materials for the distribution of the meals.ldquoWe are using the more expensive, compostable food containers and paper bags, so all items can be recycled.ldquoTo cover the extra cost towards this, we had some very generous donations from our community.

title: community-resilience-volunteers-cockenzie-port-seton-tranent-prestonpans
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at three of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port SetonCOCKENZIE and Port Setonrsquos resilience team has now delivered more than , meals to residents in the community during lockdown.The meals are made at Port Seton Centre by East Lothian Council staff, assisted by resilience volunteers who also deliver them.The ,th meal was delivered to David Finlayson, who has been shielding, by council staff member Paul Brown, who is usually based in Longniddry Community Centre.Some of the villagersquos younger residents have also been offering their services as volunteers, with the time they spend volunteering with the resilience team going towards their Saltire Awards ndash the Scottish Governmentrsquos celebration of youth volunteers.Meanwhile, the list of services on offer to residents has grown in the past week.Volunteers are now cutting grass for those whose gardens need it and are delivering books to those on the library list who would usually borrow books regularly.The latter service is being run from Port Seton Library.Cockenzie and Port Setonrsquos resilience effort is being led by the local community council, whose chairman, Bryan Hickman, told the Courier that, alongside these new developments, everything  was ldquocarrying on as normal.The resilience group has also received donations from The Seaglass Inn and Seton Burns Club, with proceeds going towards and supporting its ongoing work.A food pantry is available at Port Seton Centre pm-pm, Monday-Friday, with delivery available by calling  .The hardship fund is also continuing, supporting those whose circumstances have changed and are in need of extra support.For more information, people are asked to email ebrown@eastlothian.gov.uk or to call the centre.Those who need assistance or help of any kind can call  .PrestonpansTHE Pennypit Pantry hit a milestone last week as it recorded , meals being made since it launched its support service in March.Prestonpans Community Council praised the team behind the project for its hard work during tough times.Brian Weddell, chairman, said: ldquoThe two driving forces at The Pennypit, Debbie Reynolds and Angie Davie, lead a hard-working team of dedicated staff supplemented by the resilience volunteers.ldquoEveryone involved with supporting people in the community has their ups and downs.ldquoWe get a huge amount of positive feedback from people receiving the support however, the downside is when someone we have been helping becomes ill or passes away.ldquoPeople we have all got to know well and built friendships with have lost family members, spouses and neighbours ndash but one thing they all say is how thankful and grateful they are for the staff they see every day and for the food packages.ldquoThe pantry has become much more than just a food provision ndash our volunteers are speaking to people who are lonely, building relationships and just being a familiar and friendly face.The community resilience team is preparing for the impact of the Scottish Government lsquotest and protectrsquo strategy which could see the number of people self-isolating increase.Families and people who can support themselves are urged to use a collection service, which is available from the Pennypit Pagoda, while following social distancing and the safety procedures in place.If anyone in Prestonpans is needing support with meals or essential groceries, the Pennypit Pantry can be contacted on   or by emailing lornabellany@gmailAs well as the Pennypit Pantry, Jane Russellrsquos Sunday Chicken Dinners are still being provided and last weekend they delivered  dinners.Sunday dinners can be ordered via the East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes page on Facebook or  .Prestonpans Community Council continues to offer a hardship fund for people finding it dficult as lockdown continues, and anyone needing support should telephone the resilience hotline number on   or email prestonpansresilience@gmail.TranentTHE resilience group in Tranent and Elphinstone will be reaching out to offer support to carers in the community who may be feeling isolated.The resilience group will then be able to respond and offer these carers someone to chat to and supportitrsquos needed.Meanwhile, the resilience effort continues and volunteers have been helping those in need, from picking up shopping and prescriptions, to post office visits, deliveries and dog walking.However, these types of requests have been slowing down and volunteers are now mostly helping with food production and deliveries.The resilience team in Tranent also assists Fundamental Foods and the Pennypit Trust with meal deliveries, and has been supporting the school hub and its meal and lunch deliveries.The effort in Tranent and Elphinstone is being led by the local community council, overseen by member Mike Falconer, the grouprsquos single point of contact .Anyone who needs help can call   or email tranentemergencyresponse@gmailIn Elphinstone, Roots and Fruits is helping lsquoTeam Elphyrsquo by delivering lunches to residents and supporting people in the village.Its community food larder, offering free produce, is available noon-.pm every day for anyone who needs it.Those who need support can contact Roots and Fruits on  .Roots and Fruits also received a donation of money from Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council, which will be used to help fund and support this work.

title: racing-gets-green-light-return
story: Musselburgh Racecourse will stage the first of five meeting on the last day of the month with fixtures also planned for Wednesday, July .They will be followed by fixtures scheduled on Friday, July , Thursday, July , and Wednesday, August .The first race in Scotland since the Covid outbreaktakes place at Ayr this Monday .It is expected other fixtures will be assigned by the British Horseracing Authority in due course to Musselburgh and Scotlandrsquos other four racecourses.Musselburghrsquos management team hasestablished procedures for hosting controlled meetings without spectators which meet the highest health and safety and bio-security standards and have been working closely with East Lothian Council and Police Scotland in preparation for the resumption of racing.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, welcomed the announcement and said Scottish racing was fully prepared to play a vital role in supporting owners, trainers and the wider horseracing sector.He said: ldquoControlled horseracing meetings have been very successfully introduced in England, Ireland and a number of other countries and we are looking forward to playing our part in getting the wheels of the industry turning again in Scotland.Racing fans will be able to follow the action through a number of dferent options, including live screening on Racing TV, ITV Racing, on catch up via Racing TV Player, and through bookmakers websites for those who have accounts.Joe FitzPatrickMSP, minister for public health,sport  wellbeing, said: ldquoIrsquom sure that this news will be welcomed by racing fans across the country. The resumption of professional sports is another step towards some level of normality and its safe resumption is only possible thanks to a constructive relationship between the Scottish Government and bodies like Scottish Racing.Delly Innes, manager of Scottish Racing, said: ldquoWe are delighted to welcome theof racing in Scotland after a long, but necessary, absence as Scotland faced the challenges of Covid-. This has been an immensely challenging time for our five excellent racecourses, but this is an important first step on the road to recovery, and we will be working hard to ensure all our participants are familiar with, and adhere to Scottish rules and guidance where these dfer from UK guidance.ldquoWe are raring to go with an exciting programme of fixtures in the months ahead which will help support the wider Scottish and British racing industry, and provide entertainment to viewers across the country.

title: community-resilience-volunteers-humbie-east-west-saltoun-bolton-musselburgh-ormiston
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at four of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Humbie, East and West Saltoun, and BoltonRESIDENTS across East and West Saltoun, Humbie and Bolton continue to help and look after each other and plans are being made for how the effort will continue, once volunteers start going back to work.Derek Smith, the single point of contactin West Saltoun, said that people in the area were ldquocarrying on doing as we do and continued to look after each other.For example, two households will do the shopping for another four, and residents from another village have been delivering logs to those who need them.Derek said: ldquoWersquove been helping each other out.ldquoThe number of people in the village who need shopping, or those sheltering and so on, will continue [getting support] as long as itrsquos needed.ldquoIn a village this size, we all know each other, andanyone needs something they can knock on someonersquos door. There is always someone they can get in touch with.Considering how the effort will continue now restrictions are starting to ease, Derek said: ldquoThings may well change as people go back to work. There may be a drop of capability and volunteers able to continue on some basis.He added that the local resilience plan has been updated to include a pandemic, should one happen again in the future. Plans were previously prepared for bad weather, such as the snow seen in the lsquoBeast from the Eastrsquo.In Humbie, the first weekly soup-and-sandwich lunch was delivered last Wednesdayto local residents who are isolating or severely restricting their movements.The aim of the lunch is to provide some socially distanced contact and something for residents to look forward to each week.Al Beck, from Humbie, East  West Saltoun and Bolton Community Council, said: ldquoEverything looked great and the lunch, together with the brief visit by our volunteers, was warmly received by everyone.The project is planned to run for the next approximately eight weeks.One resident said: ldquoThank you all for the lsquosouperrsquo lunch, we really enjoyed it. Had a lovely wee chat with the lady who delivered.Another said: ldquoThank you all, my mum enjoyed her lunch and apparently was going to share her scone, but decided to eat it all herself as she said it was too good to share.Those who live in the Humbie and Fala area and are interested in the soupand-sandwich lunch, either for themselves or for someone  they know, are encouraged to get in touch with Margo Hodge.For those needing assistance, people in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by email at shenajamieson@aolEast Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahooIn West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmailIn Humbie, residents are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailMusselburghGARDENING tools are on loan through Resilient Musselburgh during the Covid- crisis.They have been provided by the Musselburgh Tool Library and everything from strimmers, lawn mowers, edgers, hedge trimmers, hoes, rakes, spades and forks can be borrowed.Tools can be booked by calling the Musselburgh community response phone line on  .They will be delivered direct to householders on a Friday morning between .am and .am and collected at the same time the following week.Jane Cummings, from East Lothian Councilrsquos Connected Communities, said: ldquoThis is a temporary service to help people maintain and enjoy their gardens during the summer months. There is no charge but tools must be booked in advance.Resilient Musselburgh also submitted a short video competition entry to Nisarsquos charity lsquoMaking a Dference Locallyrsquo on how it spent the companyrsquos pound donation, which was received in May.This video has won an award of an additional pound, towards the community response in Musselburgh, Whitecraig, Wallyford and Old Craighall.Resilient Musselburgh is being led by Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council and Musselburgh Area Partnership, helped by an army of around  volunteers.It is continuing to deliver food and prescriptions to vulnerable people in the area during the coronavirus crisis.OrmistonTHE Pennypit Community Development Trust has put out an appeal for supplies of groceries, toiletries, and other items to help them continue supplying surrounding communities during the ongoing lockdown.Ormiston Community Council said it received a fantastic response after sharing the appeal on Ormi Folks Facebook page, with several volunteers collecting donations and delivering them to St Martinrsquos Hall to be distributed.Councillors thanked everyone who contributed to the appeal.The community resilience team is currently assessing the way forward, with some volunteers now ing to work and the likelihood that some of those who needed help during the first phase of lockdown may not need as much support as the easing of restrictions continues.Scott Gillies, community council chairman, said: ldquoWe are now assessing how things will continue now that some volunteers are ing to work, and also some who were needing help during the initial lockdown period may not need as much assistance.ldquoWe feel we still have adequate cover to continue the food deliveries, carry out shopping and pick up prescriptions for the time being.If anyone in Ormiston requires help they can contact the team on   between am and pm, seven days a week, or email Ormistonrcrteam@hotmail

title: far-can-travel-scotlands-phase-2-can-drive-england
story: Early on in her briefing, Nicola Sturgeon said that as part of the ldquostaged approach, the Scottish Government guidance will continue to be asking people to ldquoas far as possible to stay within or close to their local area.She added that their ambition ldquois to be in a position to lt this in Phase  and in time for the proposed resumption of tourism from July .How far can I travel At this stage for leisure and recreation purposes, Ms Sturgeon says people should ldquonot travel more than five miles or so from their home.She added: ldquoOutdoor businesses, such as zoos and garden attractions, can also reopen from June  ndash although people should not be travelling more than five miles to visit them and tickets should be bought in advance.The retail sector is also set to open on June .However she added that, as revealed previously, the five-mile limitdoes NOT apply to meeting family and friends.These meetings should take place outdoors, but under new Phase  measures you can go inside to use the toilet.Can I travel to England A Scottish Government spokesperson says that as long as you can get there and back in one day, you can visit family in England.They told the Scotsman that it would be fine to travel to, for example, Carlisle or Berwick, to visit family ndash so long as you do not have to stay overnight.The spokesman did however advise against travelling too far, adding it would become more dficult to make it back in one day ndash urging people to ldquoexercise common sense in their actions.Can I use public transport Public transport is continuing to operate at a massively reduced capacity to allow for physical distancing.But under Phase , there will be a slight increase in services ndash but with new rules.From today, face coverings are mandatory on all public transport in Scotland, with customers urged to avoid peak times wherever possible to allow for key workers to use the services.

title: 1-650-spent-remind-residents-keep-distance
story: The ft-high information boards have been produced to remind people to follow social distancing rules as restrictions on outdoor gatherings are eased.With the message Keep East Lothian Moving, the boards remind people to maintain a two-metre distance and "consider others when youre out and about".The messages are accompanied by images of people out walking their dogs, with their families, running and cycling and an elderly person using a walking aid, as well as a skateboarder.East Lothian Council said it had invested more than pound, in the boards which will appear across  key sites.The move comes as the local authority also deployed mobile electronic signs on the A coast road over the weekend reminding people to stay local.The electronic signs, usually used to deter speeding on the road, changed its message as the council reopened its larger coastal car parks for local residents to use.They warned people not to stray too far from their home comforts with the message, Stay Local No Public Toilets.A council spokesperson said the new social distance boards would be placed at sites around the county.They said: ldquoAt this stage, we have identied  locations in dferent parts of East Lothian where these materials, highlighting the importance of physical distancing guidelines, will be put in place."Thirty copies have been ordered at a cost of pound,.

title: losing-sense-smell-coronavirus---happens
story: FROM the first reports coming out of Wuhan, Iran and later Italy, we knew that losing your sense of smellwas a signicant symptom of the disease.Now, after months of reports, both anecdotal and more rigorous clinical findings, we think we have a model for how this virus may cause smell loss.One of the most common causes of smell loss is a viral infection, such as the common cold, sinus or other upper respiratory tract infections.Those coronaviruses that donrsquot cause deadly diseases, such as COVID-, Sars and Mers, are one of the causes of the common cold and have been known to cause smell loss.In most of these cases, sense of smell s when symptoms clear, as smell loss is simply the result of a blocked nose, which prevents aroma molecules reaching olfactory receptors in the nose. In some cases, smell loss can persist for months and years.For the novel coronavirus , however, the pattern of smell loss is dferent. Many people with COVID- reported a sudden loss of sense of smell and then a sudden and fullto a normal sense of smell in a week or two.Interestingly, many of these people said their nose was clear, so smell loss cannot be attributed to a blocked nose.For others, smell loss was prolonged and several weeks later they still had no sense of smell. Any theory of anosmia in COVID- has to account for both of these patterns.This suddenof a normal sense of smell suggests an obstructive smell loss in which the aroma molecules cannot reach the receptors in the nose .Now that we have CT scans of the noses and sinuses of people with COVID- smell loss, we can see that the part of the nose that does the smelling, the olfactory cleft, is blocked with swollen soft tissue and mucus ndash known as a cleft syndrome.The rest of the nose and sinuses look normal and patients have no problem breathing through their nose.We know that the way SARS-CoV- infects the body is by attaching to ACE receptors on the surface of cells that line the upper respiratory tract.A protein called TMPRSS then helps the virus invade the cell. Once inside the cell, the virus can replicate, triggering the immune systemrsquos inflammatory response. This is the starting point for the havoc and destruction that this virus causes once in the body.Initially, we thought that the virus might be infecting and destroying the olfactory neurons.These are the cells that transmit the signal from the aroma molecule in your nose to the area in the brain where these signals get interpreted as ldquosmell.However, an international collaboration showed recently that the ACE proteins the virus needs to invade the cells were not found on the olfactory neurons.But they were found on cells called ldquosustentacular cells, which support the olfactory neurons.We expect that these support cells are likely to be the ones that are damaged by the virus, and the immune response would cause swelling of the area but leave the olfactory neurons intact.When the immune system has dealt with the virus, the swelling subsides and the aroma molecules have a clear route to their undamaged receptors and the sense of smell s to normal.So why does smell notin some cases This is more theoretical but follows from what we know about inflammation in other systems.Inflammation is the bodyrsquos response to damage and results in the release of chemicals that destroy the tissues involved.When this inflammation is severe, other nearby cells start to be damaged or destroyed by this ldquosplash damage. We believe that accounts for the second stage, where the olfactory neurons are damaged.Recovery of smell is much slower because the olfactory neurons need time to regenerate from the supply of stem cells within the lining of the nose.Initial recovery is often associated with distortion of the sense of smell known as parosmia, where things donrsquot smell like they used to.For many parosmics, for instance, the smell of coffee is often described as burnt, chemical, dirty and reminiscent of sewage.Physiotherapy for the noseOlfaction has been called the Cinderella of the senses because of its neglect by scientic research.But it has come to the forefront in this pandemic. The silver lining is that we will learn a lot about how viruses are involved in smell loss from this. But what hope is there for people with a loss of smell now The good news is that the olfactory neurons can regenerate. Theyrsquore regrowing in almost all of us, all of the time. We can harness that regeneration and guide it with ldquophysiotherapy for the nose: smell training.

title: headteacher-praised-leadership-style
story: North Berwick High Schools head Lauren Rodgerwas described by Education Scotland inspectors as having a clear direction and being well respected.However while the inspection, carried out in February,praised the staff and leadership at the school and achievements of its senior students, it pointed to improvements required to enable more S-S pupils to learn a foreign language.The report called for more work to be done to ensure all younger students received their full entitlement to Broad General Educationin the first three years at the school.In particular it stated: "Currently, a few young people are not experiencing a modern language until the end of S."Inaddition, the current arrangement is not sufficient for young people to receive their entitlementto a meaningful experience of a third language."Inspectors urged the school to ensure the focus was on ensuring younger pupils received full access to experiences across the curriculum and did not allow a focus on reaching exam levels to impact on them.The inspectors said: "Teachers should ensure that learning at Sacross all curriculum areas remains focused on the experiences and outcomes of CfEanddoes not prioritise the requirements of National Qualications ."Senior and middle leadersshould ensure that learning experiences in S provide those young people specialising atfourth level with appropriate depth in their learning to provide successful progression to thesenior phase."Inspectors visited the school in February  and assessed the schoolrsquos performance across four key indicators: leadership of change learning, teaching and assessment raising attainment and achievement and ensuring wellbeing, equality and inclusion.The school was evaluated as lsquovery goodrsquo in the first three categories and lsquogoodrsquo in the fourth.Headteacher Lauren Rodgerrsquos leadership style was described as ldquocharacterised by openness and by trust, promoting empowerment in a supportive ethos. Inspectors highlighted the strong leadership at all staff levels and the use of effective research to support creative learning.Innovative approaches to teaching and assessment encourage young people to take responsibility for their own learning. Where young people are facing personal challenges, the report noted that targeted strategies are used to support them, and an open climate exists within the school around mental health.As part of the process, inspectors make recommendations for areas of improvement. The letter outlines recommendations that the school continues with its improvements to the planning process for S-S and reviews its approaches for checking on pupilrsquos wellbeing.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, East Lothian Councils cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoIrsquod like to congratulate Lauren Rodger and her team on a very positive report. The inspectorsrsquo comments regarding strong leadership and how this supports pupilsrsquo attainment through creative learning and personal responsibility is a real testament to the school teamrsquos positive work and ethos."Thisreport will provide confidence and comfort for parents and carers, and is much-welcomed good news for the school community.Lesley Brown, chief operating officer for education at the local authority, said: ldquoIrsquom sure this report will be welcomed by everyone connected with North Berwick High School."Irsquom especially pleased to see inspectors recognise the work that staff and pupils have undertaken to open-up conversations around mental health and wellbeing."This will be especially important in the months ahead as weto school, and is very much in line with our approach to use nurture to help reconnect and recover from Covid. Irsquod like to commend Lauren Rodger and her team on their achievements and their commitment to creating such strong learning opportunities.

title: staycation-five-scotlands-photogenic-places-visit-lockdown-eases
story: After exactly three months of lockdown things are starting to look up ndash and just last week it was revealed Scotlandrsquos tourism sector ndash including hotels, pubs and restaurants ndash could reopen from July .And with our beautul scenery, immersing history and friendly locals, therersquos no wonder why some research shows more than half of Brits are eyeing up a lsquostaycationrsquo this year rather than opting to go abroad.With that in mind, wersquove detailed outfiveof the most photogenic lsquostaycationrsquo locations to visit in Scotland once lockdown measures are eased.Harris, Outer HebridesWhen thinking about a lsquostaycationrsquo in Scotland, itrsquos understandable that a beach holiday isnrsquot the first thing on your mind.But the Outer Hebrides beaches are some of the most beautul in Europe ndash and it would be hard to blame youyou thought it was somewhere in the Caribbeanhellip perhaps only the temperature would give it away.In March, Luskentyre Bay on Harris was named as one of the top  beaches in the world by Tripadvisor.The far-flung, sandy outpost - which is reached by a single track road - was rated higher than sun-soaked destinations in Spain, the Caribbean, and the golden shores of Florida to take th spot in the prestigious s Travellers Choice Awards.Described by the sites visitors "as close to heaven as you could get", the expanse of Luskentyre Bay sits on the South of Harris, close to the isolated island of Taransay, where the seminal BBC reality series Castaway  was filmed.Tobermory, MullIt doesnrsquot take a tourism expert to identy the colourful harbour-front buildings of Tobermory from the popular childrenrsquos TV show Balamory.The capital of Mull, Tobermory is arguably one of the prettiest ports in Scotland thanks to the before-mentioned colourful houses and sheltered bay.Legend has it that Tobermory was the location of the sinking of Spanish Armada ship in , carrying gold bullion.You can find out all about the history of the area in the Mull museum ndash orgolf is more of your fancy then therersquos a nine-hole course sitting in the clfs above the bay.The ldquotough challenge offers panoramic views across to the Ardnamurchan Peninsula and, on a clear day, the Isle of Skye.The bay is also a departure point for whale watching and wildle cruises.Eilean Donan, HighlandsItrsquos the most photographed castle in Scotland and has been featured in blockbuster films including James Bond.Recognised around the world as one of the most iconic images of Scotland, itrsquos little wonder the castle is now one of the most visited attractions in the Scottish Highlands.Strategically located on its own little island overlooking the isle of Skye, the castle sits where three lochs ndash Loch Duich, Loch Long and Loch Alsh meet.Surrounded by the mountains of Kintail, visitors have the chance to wander around the internal rooms of the castle while also taking in the wonderful wildle that surrounds the island too ndash with porpoise, dolphins, otters and birdle sightings an often occurrence.Arran, North AyrshireThe Isle of Arran is often described as ldquoScotland in Miniature, soyoursquore looking for a quick staycation but with a lot to experience then look no further.The ever-changing coastline, dramatic mountain peaks, sheltered beaches and tasty local produce makes a holiday in Arran unforgettable.Donrsquot forget to pack your camera ndash with the stunning views of and from the islandrsquos largest mountain, Goatfell, worth capturing.Not only that but the island boasts a wealth of nature, including red squirrels, deer, golden eagles, otters, seals and basking sharks just waiting to be snapped up.Glenfinnan Viaduct, HighlandsMade ever more popular by the Harry Potter films, the Glenfinnan Viaduct attracts thousands of visitors from across the world every year.The special atmosphere and the stunning scenery overlooking the famous railway track makes for some magical images ndash no wonder why they chose it for the wizarding films.The famous viaduct carries the railway to Glenfinnan station across a ft span, ft above the ground ndash and the Jacobite steam train runs from here to Fort William and Mallaig in the summer months.Visitors are reminded, however, that trespassing on the railway line is extremely dangerous and they should stay clear of the tracks at all times.Full details of all the locations and more are available on Visit Scotlands website here.And remember: Do not travel for leisure until the Scottish Government guidance says it is acceptable to do so.

title: bbc-tv-licence-payments-75s-delayed-october
story: It comes after anational newspaper reported earlier thisweek on theintroduction of mandatory TV licences for over s - suggesting they would be making them pay the annual charge ofpound.from this October, rather thanAugust.However, the BBC have quickly moved to clary the situation.What have the BBC said In relation to an article published in the , aBBC spokesperson said: ldquoThe BBC has made no such decision and it is wrong to suggest we have."The BBCs position is that we have delayed implementation until August - and we are doing what we have always said - which is keeping that decision under review."The BBC will announce its decision in July."Why were the plans delayed Initially, over-s would have had to begin paying in June, but plans were pushed back to August in the wake of the coronavirus crisis.TV licenses were deemed necessary in keeping over-s - who are more at risk from the effects of Covid- - informed as the pandemic spread.Chairman of the BBC, Sir David Clementi, said at the time: "The BBC board has decided to delay changes to over s licence fees."We are in exceptional circumstances. Now is not the right time. We are fully focused on delivering our services to the public at this dficult time."Reaction to the moveLord Foulkes, the chairman of the All-Party Group for Ageing and Older People, said: "The Government should cover the cost as a social benefit and not burden the BBC, which is already strapped for cash."We will continue to work on this vital campaign alongside the likes of Age UK, as well as a growing number of MPs and peers."Caroline Abrahams, the charity director at Age UK, added: "While many older people are being advised to stay mostly at home, or are too worried to go out, free TV licences for over-s should continue."The last thing they need is to have to get to grips with a new TV licence scheme, or risk prosecutionthey get it wrong."When were free TV licences for over s introduced Free TV licences for over s were introduced by Labour PM Gordon Brown, and were first paid for by a Labour government in .

story: Nicola Sturgeon stressed there is no change to the two-metre social distancing rule just yet, as she set out some new key indicative dates for when some measures and phased can come into effect.This is reliant on a continued suppression of the virus in Scotland.Here, we detail out the six key dates you need to know with their lockdown changes.Full details can be found here.ShoppingOutdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.The First Minister also outlined plans for non-essential retail units to reopen form June  - but these will have to have outside entrances.
